## Contributing

The project is in maintenance mode, meaning, changes are driven by contributed patches.
There is otherwise no active development or roadmap for this project. It is "DIY".

Only proposed changes in the form of a pull request are likely to be acted on, but,
these will be acted on promptly.

### Questions

Questions should be asked on the mailing list:
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/zxing

### Feature Requests

Feature requests are not accepted and will generally be closed.
Feature requests with a pull request may be accepted. When in doubt, discuss on the
mailing list first.

### Bug Reports

Bug reports must have enough detail to understand and reproduce the problem. Inadequate
bug reports will be closed with a request for more information.

Bug reports without an associated pull request are not likely to be addressed, but will be
left open for some time to see if anyone can contribute a solution. However, bug reports
with a pull request are likely to be merged promptly.

This isn't an app problem. SOmething's wrong with your Android or build.

It happens in a number of devices (Galaxy S5, Galaxy A7, Galaxy Note4, Galaxy A5, Galaxy Tab2 10.1, Google Pixel, Galaxy Alpha, Galaxy S7, ...), I checked the apk file running "unzip -lv <file_name>.apk" and the zxing_beep.ogg is not compressed apparently.
I don't think it's a problem of the build, is there anyway to disable that beep programmatically?

Is there a mapping from ZXing version to JDK version?
I'm trying to decide if I need to explicitly set the JDK version that I used for my build in the manifest file.
example: 
zxing 2.2  -->jdk 1.6 above
zxing 2.3  -->jdk 1.7 above
Waiting for your help , your reply will be appreciate!
Questions should go to the mailing list, but you can also find that release 3.0.0 requires Java 7+ from the Releases tab. Before that, I believe 2.x required Java 6, and before that it was Java 4+.

Thanks for your answer. I search the realse tab. I find the description of the java version .
But I find that the earliest version of ZXing is 2.3.0. Where can I find the old version source file and description  of zxing .Example: ZXing 2.2.0,etc.
Waiting for your help , your reply will be appreciate!

Hi!
I'm trying to scan large Aztec code (size 151x151 modules). Unfortunately scanner don't recognize them.
I've read that it's not only my problem.

Platform: Android

Example Aztec code:
![407sw](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/283599/24083353/f32cdd3c-0cd5-11e7-8dc0-0a8cb83d2f12.jpg)
I think it is just too big to read. A bit flatter and clearer would probably work.

Unfortunately presented code is not generated by my system, but it's needed to red in polish vehicle registration card. 
Is there any possibility to read this code by zxing library? Maybe you should pull request for some optimization in the source code?

My system read it once but can't anymore (400 error on ship.ly something).
Try flatter like Sean said.

-LP

Not a problem and not related to Java.  This constant is deprecated in newer Android but is used for backward compatibility

Moved a couple of calculations out of for loops if they aren't affected by the for loop to avoid recalculating the same value.

Hello, I am a Android developer from China, is using the 3.3.0 version of the library, a problem encountered in the development:
I recognize the CODE_128 format of the bar code, the content is 99770280035299, in the frame offset slightly to the left or right of about 20 degrees, will be identified as such as UPC_E, EAN_8 format, such as [UPC_E]01723047, [UPC_E]12668515, [EAN_8]18788082 content, test mobile phone Samsung GalaxyGrand2, xiaomi4S, OPPOA59M, HUAWEI enjoy 5S.
At present, I can only shield UPC_E and EAN_8 format, I would like to ask the above problems have a better solution? Thank you
——————————————————————————
您好，我是一名来自中国的安卓开发者，正在使用3.3.0版本的库，开发中遭遇一个问题：
我在识别CODE_128格式的条码，内容是99770280035299，在取景框稍微向左或向右偏移大约20度时，会识别为如UPC_E、EAN_8格式，内容如[UPC_E]01723047、[UPC_E]12668515、[EAN_8]18788082，测试手机为三星GalaxyGrand2、xiaomi4S、OPPOA59M、华为畅享5S。
目前我只能屏蔽UPC_E与EAN_8格式，请问以上问题有更优的解决方案吗？谢谢！
hello,Can you give me some advice on this question?
Can you give me some advice on this question?

Program does not change the camera resolution to the max resolution temporally for scanning

ie. I usually have my 16mp camera set for 2mp for web photos. 
when I open the app the scanner uses 2mp  setting for scanning.  this is trouble because at 2mp I cannot get a UPC-E Scan.

Thanks for maintaining zxing, it's probably the best open source library for barcodes out there.

Currently, I am trying to scan datamatrix codes, however, scan performance is not very good (see attachment), especially with larger (6x6) datamatrix codes. Scanning from my screen while the codes are enlarged is doable, but It's nearly impossible to scan the attached codes from printed pages.

I am aware that this project is in maintenance mode and this is more or less a feature request. However, if you could point me in the direction of some other library (or just the necessary optimizations) which offer/s better datamatrix scan performance, I would be happy integrate the code into zxing and file a pull request.

Attached file:
[Testfälle_bmp023.pdf](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/files/799996/Testfalle_bmp023.pdf)

Further information and background:
Germany has decided to standardize medication plans (see examples in attachment pdf). They chose to use datamatrix instead of qr codes (hm). The first smartphone apps in the app stores seem to be licensing proprietary scan technology.

So at the moment our options are:
- Everyone licenses proprietary scanners
- Change the standard from datamatrix to qr codes (better scanning performance)

If we don't find an open-source library which delivers satisfactory datamatrix scanning performance, we're in for a fun ride..

Any answer is greatly appreciated. Thanks!
I don't have any suggestions for you, and wouldn't dump another library into this one. If you have a more targeted PR to suggest, you can open one.

Doesn't it need to be 10 if the max index is 9?

@srowen, yes, you're correct, whoops. I'm currently porting the 1D barcode code to JavaScript as part of extending [Schibum/barcode.js](https://github.com/Schibum/barcode.js/) to also work with 1D barcodes which is why I noticed this. Having the array be too large was causing a failure because of a for loop over the patterns running into uninitialized values (NaN). Since arrays in JavaScript are dynamic by making it 9 instead of 10 it still worked because the array just expanded to 10 and I didn't notice. Too many late nights, not enough coffee.

I'll fix pull request to change it to 10.

That's odd, I have never seen that error. However, the pom file for this artifact does look like it has an error:

http://search.maven.org/#artifactdetails%7Ccom.github.jai-imageio%7Cjai-imageio-core%7C1.3.1%7Cbundle

Barcode scanner seems to be using different type defaults for `ADR` and `TEL` than suggested in the specification (at least for vCard 2.1). For me it defaults to 'private' but it should to 'work'. From looking at the code it seems that there is no default internally. This can also result in wrong order of types, e.g. this vCard data will swap the types of the second and third number.  

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

IMHO a good solution for both issues would be to default to the type 'WORK' for phone numbers and addresses at parse time. This should be close enough to the specification. Maybe also for eMails.  

I guess this could be implemented by adding a `defaultType` Parameter to the function `matchVCardPrefixedField` in VCardResultParser.java?

I skimmed the code again and it seems like it defaults to nothing at all when there's no type metadata. "private" is perhaps an Android default. I don't know if this app should do something different.

What's the scenario where the types are wrong though? That does sound like a problem. The 'types' and values arrays should be of equal length. Are you on the trail of a fix already? if you have a PR to look at, I'll review. Maybe this as a test case plus some extra arg checking would reveal the issue.

Yes, it seems "private" is the Android default. I think it would be best for ZXing to itself insert a default of "work" as that is the recommended default in the vCard spec.  
  
The vCard data above ( [QR Code from it in ZXing Generator](https://zxing.org/w/chart?cht=qr&chs=350x350&chld=L&choe=UTF-8&chl=BEGIN%3AVCARD%0AN%3A%3BJohn%3B%3B%3B%0ATEL%3BWORK%3A10%0ATEL%3A2%0ATEL%3BCELL%3A30%0AEND%3AVCARD++) ) results in a wrong type for "2" and "30". The reason for this seems to be that the 'types' and 'values' arrays are NOT of equal length as "2" in the example does not get a type. Would it get a default type ("work") everything should work as expected.  
  
Unfortunately I am not fluent in Java but I *think* a fix for both issues could look like this:  
* add ´defaultType´ parameter to the function ´matchVCardPrefixedField´.
* in ´AddressBookParsedResult´ append default values ´work´ to the fields ´ADR´, ´TEL´ and ´EMAIL´

Yeah I have a fix for the actual bug, that part was simple. Do you have a ref for the vCard default? I intend the output of parsing the vCard as a POJO to reflect the source. If it always says 'WORK' when nothing is specified that's kind of changing what the data says. Unless vCard mandates that all contact info has a type and defaults to work I'd hesitate to apply that change.

Taking a closer look, the defaults are not so clear after all.  
  
vCard 2.1: https://www.imc.org/pdi/vcard-21.rtf   searching for `Delivery Address Type` there is a table. It says the default includes several odd types but I think ´WORK´ is most relevant, at least for Android  
vCard 3.0: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2426#page-20 same defaults as 2.1 for ´ADR´
vCard 4.0: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6350#page-20 defaults to none for ´ADR´ (which is impossible on Android I guess).  
  
For ´TEL´ the default is "VOICE" for all three versions and for ´EMAIL´ the default is "INTERNET" for v2.1 and v3.0 and nothing for v 4.0.  

As long as Android enforces a default it seems to to be impossible to get a result according to the spec. And the moral of the story is that types always need to be included. Still, it might be better to use "WORK" instead of an Android enforced "PRIVATE" as default as probably 99% of vCards are business vCards.
Yeah that is a reasonable argument for enforcing a default, even if there isn't one, really. I end up neutral on it and would prefer to leave that behavior as-is, if neutral.

This is a copy-and-paste-and-change of the Interleaved 2-of-5 reader to support the non-interleaved or standard variant of the Bar-Code.
Two black-box tests also supplied, test suit passes.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io?src=pr). Last update [cdf4fe5...adf9174](https://codecov.io/gh/zxing/zxing/compare/cdf4fe51c5dd08f12fa45e55c953931732764ad2...adf917426ebf442176c04f9b3987a0e836fce193?src=pr)

I've attempted to change as little as possible.
The narrow line width is a side-result of checking for the start pattern (it's calculated there). I suppose a two phase process could be implemented.
I've attempted to re-factor the code so that both standard and interleaved 2-of-5 are read with the same class. This came out to be very messy, since the two codes are similar, but the differences are quite significant. I have not tried re-factoring a common abstract base, but it seems achievable.
This symbology is somewhat side-lined, since a better Interleaved variant has outscored it, but the issue has been brought more than once on the mailing list. 
This symbology seems to be the Industrial or Standard 2-of-5. The only source about this code I can find is http://www.barcodeisland.com/2of5.phtml.
Unlike the Interleaved variant this symbology can be written using a font: http://www.barcodefonts.net/Industrial2of5_Barcode.html
The symbology is only mentioned on the Wikipedia https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barcode#Linear_barcodes

I'd prefer not to merge this because the list is intended to be only the app's package and 'official' derivatives. It's a bit of a slippery slope otherwise: how many more to list? how to verify they faithfully support the intent? the package name of the app you propose implies the main app isn't 'privacy safe', which isn't a bit true.

What we could however look at is allowing targeting no package at all and letting any app respond to the intent. The problem is potentially triggering an app that doesn't actually properly support the intent, but, suppose that is up to the caller since it wouldn't be the default.

And we furthermore don't assume that other apps have privacy issues by default.  
We have send the PR as a user request (see https://github.com/SilenceIM/Silence/issues/330).  I guess your suggestion could be a solution and of course it's up to you to decide.

Interesting, but what does this help? the app can't do anything until the camera opens anyway, so it kind of blocks on this anyway. Other init is trivial.

@srowen Android has a strict rule that you shouldn't perform long running executions on the main thread, this essentially follows that principle and offloads `camera.open()` to background worker thread, I can add more improvements on this where in I also offload `camera.release()` to this worker thread. Blocking the UI thread is a no no in my book, also the difference in User experience is that of between heaven and earth. You can run the apk on your device and have a look yourself. There is a 50-100 frames drop due to the `camera.open` call which is removed in this PR.

@srowen any updates on this? Can you at least explain why you are adamant about not having this feature put in? I mean it doesn't beak anything, and it actually improves activity launch speed, I have tested this on more than 10 manufacturer devices (including samsung) and it works perfectly normal. May I know whats keeping you apprehensive?

@srowen from my personal testing I have observed that the scan speed deteriorates due to this change, could you hopefully shed some light on why this might happen? I will update the PR with a fix, as far as I can observer that is the only issue I have encountered so far with the change.

I don't understand what this helps, because the app must block (from the user's perspective) until the camera is ready no matter what. Yes, you could conceivably do other init while waiting, but it takes essentially no time. Blocking the user thread doesn't matter here because the app is not otherwise active.

More generally, I do not have any time to maintain the app anymore, and I can't test this or support it if it doesn't work. I think it's a bit risky as every time I've changed something with the camera in the past it's broken some device's odd driver behavior. The current behavior is, at least, quite safe.

Hello, 

I'm currently working on an app, which exploits the error correction. I already read the qr specification and on page 45 I found the formula: 

"e + 2t ≤ d - p 
where: 
e = number of erasures 
t = number of errors 
d = number of error correction codewords 
p = number of misdecode protection codewords" 

where p=0 since i'm working with 3-H codes. After creating 11 errors in the data codewords of the first block, I cannot scan, which should be possible according to the formula. Is this a bug? 

QR Code with 11 errors; not scannable:
![qrcode_11errors](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3286570/20789912/7daa4b2c-b7b6-11e6-908b-3c6fa9bf78a9.png)

QR Code with 10 errors; scannable:

Carsten
Off the top of my head - error correction is per block right? You may have more errors loaded into one of the data blocks than it can handle even if the overall error count isn't that high.

Thanks for replying:
I created 11 errors in the first 11 data codewords of block 1, which consist of total 13 data codewords. Since for error correction two error correction codewords are needed (first locate and then correct) I assume, that when I have 22 error correction codewords in block 1, that I can correct 11 errors.
You can't have that many errors in one block. The EC doesn't span blocks.

What you mean bei EC doesn't span blocks? In 3-H QRCodes I have 2 blocks, where they consists of 13 data codewords and 22 error correction codewords. If I manipulate the data codewords of only block 1 and in total manipulate 11 of 13 I should be able to decode the message according to the formula.

I just went through the specification again: In Table 9 of the document "Error correction characteristics for QR Code 2005" it even states that a 3-H QR-Code has a error correction capacity of 11 errors in each block.

Have you found an app which can scan it correctly? If not, that would seem to indicate either:
1. You're interpreting the specs wrong, or
2. The specs are correct, but no one else has it working either.

Yeah, it's just one of those cases where the heuristics get it wrong. It doesn't find the corner correctly in the first image because of how it happens to search. The idea is that in the context of a phone this won't matter because the next frame probably decodes. If you have a suggestion that improves the heuristic without causing more failures than it saves, open a PR, otherwise I'd close this.

My approach so far has been to crop the image sent to the decoder around the center of the barcode rather than sweeping it across the entire width (which I'm actively trying to avoid). I use a 20px all-white border which seems to help the detector along.

Admittedly, I haven't taken a close look at the heuristic but I'd like to understand why my approach works and if/when it won't. If you want to close this ticket I can open another if I find something actionable.

I think I see what's going on with this barcode. The WhiteRectangleDetector finds the segment in the center and gives up because it is surrounded by white... My fix would be to check if all the bits are set within the located segment and if so continue searching for the corners.

pointA = {ResultPoint@2105} "(307.0,215.0)"
pointB = {ResultPoint@2108} "(308.0,271.0)"
pointC = {ResultPoint@2107} "(329.0,214.0)"
pointD = {ResultPoint@2109} "(332.0,271.0)"

EDIT: rather than simply look for a segment with all bits set we can check for non-zero transition counts between all the corner points. that should cover all cases.

Aha, yeah, it happens to find this region when searching outwards from the center. The region no longer contains the image center though when shifted a bit. You could imagine non-continuous regions in the middle that cause the same problem. It's hard to know when it's a false positive.

Hi,
  I am using zxing Barcode Scanner , I found it can not decode a utf-8 encoded Chinese String.but I use some apps can decode the QR code correctly .such as wechat .Taobao.  if I encode the String with GBK to generate QR code，it works find 。 I traced the code in zxing/core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/qrcode/decoder/DecodedBitStreamParser.java  .   I found the decoder goes to wrong mode.    mode = Mode.forBits(bits.readBits(4));  the result is Mode.KANJI .so it calls decodeKanjiSegment method next。the full messy code is “201610170063400000010285，麻譚冗浹逕伜哨譛肴��，兽药字（2012）050036112，蒙瑞普大地，0472-2209620”，and the right String is “201610170063400000010285，麻杏石甘口服液，兽药字（2012）050036112，蒙瑞普大地，0472-2209620”
> step 1 ： NUMERIC  mode  we got  “201610170063400000010285”
> step 2 ：BYTE  mode  we got  “，麻”
> step 3：KANJI mode  we got  “譚冗浹逕伜哨譛肴”  this step was wrong the String should be 杏石甘口....
> step 4： BYTE  mode  we got  “��，兽药字（2012）”  the messy code in this step i think is related with step 3.
> step 5：NUMERIC  mode  we got  “050036112”
> step 6：BYTE  mode  we got  “，蒙瑞普大地，0472-”
> step 7：NUMERIC  mode  we got  “2209620”

you can find the QR code picture： http://pan.baidu.com/s/1c1CsJNq

can you tell me why this happens？or actually  I can not encode the String with UTF-8 in the frist place？but why WeChat and taobao can decode it。

It definitely reads UTF-8, and therefore Chinese characters encoded in UTF-8. You would have to use BYTE mode, and would have to make sure it starts with an ECI segment that specifies UTF-8. Otherwise it's not guaranteed to work, and relies on the reader 'guessing' than it's UTF-8.

I can't see the barcode at your link so can't debug, but, that is likely the problem.

yes ,it works well at the most of time.but in this case it doesn't work. Same QR code pic which WetChat TaoBao can read,but zxing can not .I can't located the root cause of this issue.I think the problem it not the decoder try to "guessing" the encoding of the string.the problem is zxing goes to the wrong mode (it choose KANJI instead of BYTE mode,so it use `StringUtils.SHIFT_JIS` to decode directly which lead to a messy output). but I am sure there must be some reasons  lead two results from one QR code.

Hi,srowen

any update?

Update on what? I explained the problem already. The QR code you describe apparently does not include an ECI segment specifying UTF-8, so it is not valid. The TaoBao reader apparently always guesses a Chinese language encoding, which is fine, but not generally correct. The Barcode Scanner app must work correctly everywhere in the world. You need to fix your QR code.

I found it better to not use this mode becouse it sets focus on start and then never tweak it again later. 

It is returned in AutofocusManager as currentFocusMode and maks useAutoFocus == false.

For me it worked better if currentFocusMode is 'auto' than 'continous-video' becouse it start autofocusing by focus() and autoFocusAgainLater() by AutoFocusManager. 

"... The focus position is locked after autoFocus call ...."
source:

hi people , how use zxing on ruby ( nooo jruby ) ?

A couple related improvements from https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/zxing/iCODr5bZKHk
- UPC-E, EAN-13 and EAN-8 writers should add check digit if not present, like UPC-A does.
- They should all check the check digit if provided and reject the barcode if it fails
- The default margin for UPC/EAN barcodes should never result in a margin less than the mandated 9 modules
- Experiment with less tolerance of small quiet zones

Sean, I took a (very) quick look at your changes. It may very well be that I am not seeing things right, but I just wanted to make sure.

UPC-E checksum is not the same as an application of UPC-A algorithm over a shorter string of data, but rather requires non-intuitive UPC-E->UPC-A conversion (see the table at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_Product_Code#UPC-E) and then an application of the UPC-A calculation over it. To achieve that, I would imagine a code similar to com.google.zxing.oned.UPCEReader.convertUPCEtoUPCA should appear somewhere in the picture. I am not sure I caught that anywhere, but again, I am not super-familiar with zxing code.

I just whipped up a home grown UPC-E checksum augmenter, and it was not producing readable code images until I used UPCEReader.convertUPCEtoUPCA over the data prior to checksum calculation (working around the fact this method will actually insist on a UPC-E checksum being in the data already).

I think you're right, although it may weirdly be true that it works out the same. I will push a fix that more explicitly makes the UPC-E into UPC-A and then gets the check digit. (I should also enforce the first digit being 0 or 1.) EAN-8 does have a check digit computed directly in the same way as EAN-13 but that's not quite the same.
Great stuff, thanks!
There's a similar issue with DATA_MATRIX, it needs a quiet zone of at least one X-dimension to be readable...

When decoding QR Code in binary mode assume encoding ISO-8859-1 instead of the platform default.

Ah right, I was going to suggest instead including the ECI segment when encoding even if it encodes ISO-8859-1. Because that will also always override the guessing here, I believe. And, you can force it with a decoding hint, too. What do you think of that instead?

The only odd thing about this change is that you return ISO-8859-1 knowingly when it's been 'ruled out'. But, in general the platform default might have been one of the ones ruled out anyway.

I'm reluctant to make this change because I suspect it ends up making some Chinese QR codes not work, because they (incorrectly) use a Chinese encoding, and hey at least this would often end up getting it right on Chinese devices.

Right. That seems like a no-win situation.
There is a work-around to force ISO-8859-1 ECI to be added by specifying "ISO8859_1" character set. But still there are other ways to generate QR Codes, and those codes may still omit ECI for ISO-8859-1.

But I can see how character set from platform assumption has its merits.

![test4x4](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22150591/18505019/7c93baea-7a65-11e6-8d57-8d54195d4a83.png)

Yeah it doesn't like part of the encoding. It decodes fine up until a bit that starts "Acetylsalicyls"; is the word "Acetylsalicylsäure"? There's an upper shift followed by change to Shift 3, and then the codeword "2".

I read the spec, and it's kind of confusing about what's supposed to happen. Clearly the barcode is trying to encode the code point '132' which is 'ä' in extended ASCII. The spec refers to "extended ASCII" repeatedly, but says that code points > 127 are interpreted "as in ISO 8859 1". The code point of 'ä' in ISO 8859 1 is 228 though. In addition, I would expect code point 132 to be encoded as 3, not 2, given what I can understand of the rules.

I know that the existing tests do _not_ cover this decoder path, so it's possible it doesn't implement the spec correctly.

Hi,

I'm experimenting with ITF codes, however the scanner is not always accurate.
For example, I have use barcode-generator.org to generate code for 10101010.
When I scan it though, sometimes it scans as 76767676 and sometimes as 13131313.
It may scan incorrectly once in 10 scans. Samsung Galaxy s5, default example project.

How can I improve the accuracy of scanning?

ITF has no checksum IIRC, so it's easy to get false reads. This is why the possible lengths it will return is limited, and you can ask it to ignore anything but a read of a certain length if you know it ahead of time to avoid this. It's not really a bug, in the sense that it's always possible to see a phantom barcode, and this format is particularly prone to it.
The question is closed

... and/or duplicate of https://github.com/zxing/zxing/issues/576

The [DecoderResult class](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/blob/master/core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/common/DecoderResult.java#L28) has a getRawBytes() method returning a byte array with the raw code's content. Problem is, there's no way to know exactly how many bits are in there: up to 7 bits in the last byte can be unused (in which case they are zeroes, and indistinguishable from actual bits at zero). This can be a cause of ambiguity, to the point that codes with different contents can have the same RawBytes, defeating its use as an inspection tool. For examples, these two Aztec codes both have RawBytes
`f5 55 55 75 6b 5a d6 b5 ad 6b 5a d6 b5 ad 6b 5a d6 b5 ad 6b 5a d6 b0`
but the left one one contains
`88888TTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTT`
while the right one contains
`88888TTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTO`
![t](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7809433/17342852/69115698-58fb-11e6-8e4d-846751baa59a.png)                       ![to](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7809433/17340857/46a7eada-58f2-11e6-8711-e7c5f4fed16b.png) Both are plain vanilla Aztec codes generated with [bwip-js](http://bwip-js.metafloor.com/demo/demo.html) using `format=full eclevel=31` and their respective content. At the end of the rawBytes, the `b0` byte actually contains the bits `1001` in the left code and `10010000` in the right code, and that changes the decoded content. The issue is one of design of the DecoderResult class. I see two ways to fix this: 1. Extend the DecoderResult class (in package com.google.zxing.common) with a getRawBytesBitSize() method returning an int telling how many bits there are in what getRawBytes() returns. This will leave any existing code working (including zxing's own test code), and requires no change in existing decoders when they never leave unused bits in RawBytes, or when that somewhat does not matter. 2. Fill any unused bits of the last byte in RawBytes with bits at one rather than zero in package com.google.zxing.aztec.decoder. That makes it possible to unambiguously decode RawBytes into content of the Aztec code for any standard-conforming Aztec code, because extra one bits can only produce content if the length of an earlier byte shift sequence was followed by less than 8 times that number of bits (something ISO/IEC 24778:2008 does not condone). Method 1 is certain to cause no compatibility issue, but makes the full interface of the DecoderResult class more complex, Method 2 might not be extensible to all symbologies (if any other turns out to be affected by the limitation of the design of the DecoderResult class), often modifies the last byte in RawBytes returned for a given Aztec code (which in turn will require simple changes to zxing's test code specific to the Aztec decoder), and could conceivably silently break some existing application code. On the other hand this method - is likely to fix existing application code decoding RawBytes according to ISO/IEC 24778:2008; - ensures that when rebuilding a code from its RawBytes alone, even when the image is different (which can still happen), the content is the same (with aforementioned exceptions involving non-conforming original; also, attempted rebuilding could still fail if the few extra bits cause the maximum capacity to become exceeded); - makes the existing [ZXing Decoder Online](https://zxing.org/w/decode.jspx) and similar tools more useful as a debugging aid if left without modification to show what the hypothetical new getRawBytesBitSize() gives; - causes the less code bloat. Any thoughts on what's the way to go?

Yes, the meaning of 'raw bytes' varies a bit from barcode format to format. In any format there may be 0, 1 or more intermediate stages that might be regarded as the 'raw' payload and might be represented as bytes. For QR codes it's obviously the codewords and those are bytes. 

For Aztec is it not possible to know from the bytes where it ends? it sounds like it is not, that additional 0 bits make it still a perfectly valid result bit set.

I think the best solution is returning the number of bits that are valid, indeed, and have some logic to default it to the number of bytes times 8 of course. Then the change is pretty minimal.

Great, thanks a lot for this.

ZXing (as of July 25, 2016) decodes the following Aztec code as 3333h3i3j33333, when that should I believe be 3333h3i3jITIT per a literal reading of the ISO/IEC 24778:2008 standard, and is what I get with at least one popular decoder independent of ZXing (NeoReader). ![dlusbs.png](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7809433/17298916/4fe36296-580c-11e6-8345-6ba524b7d232.png) The binary sequence in that code, before applying the process of _14.5.2 Interpreting the bit stream_ in the standard, is the bit sequence 11110010101010101010111111111100101011010000011001101101001001100110110101001010101010101010101 which parses to The discrepancy boils down to diverging interpretation of : > Byte Shift (B/S) is a special case, shifting into a run length-controlled string of literal 8-bit bytes. Following a B/S is a 5-bit binary value: if non-zero, it encodes the number of bytes (1 to 31) that follow, but if zero then the next 11 bits encode the number of bytes less 31. Byte Shift can thus encode either isolated extended ASCII or control characters or long strings of byte data, possibly filling the whole symbol. At the end of the byte string, **encoding returns to the _mode_ from which B/S was invoked**. The closest thing to a definition of _mode_ would be > The Upper and Lower code sets contain upper and lowercase alphabetic characters respectively; Mixed contains a mixture of ASCII control and punctuation characters; Punctuation contains common punctuation characters and combinations; and Digit contains the numerals plus some punctuation (..)
Message encoding starts in the Upper code set, and can be latched (semi-permanently, via U/L, L/L, M/L, P/L, or D/L) or shifted (for one character only, via U/S or P/S) into the other _modes_ as needed. In a literal interpretation, _mode_ means one of Upper, Lower, Mixed, Punctuation, and Digit; we are in Upper mode after U/S (even though that's only until the next character); thus "the _mode_ from which B/S was invoked" is Upper; thus we return to the Upper mode at the end of the Byte Shift sequence; and further, since there has been at least one character ( h ) in the Byte Shift sequence, the temporary Upper Shift has ceased to be in effect when the decoder _returns to the mode from which B/S was invoked_. The interpretation made by ZXing could to be that _the next character_ after U/S is B/S, and that ends the Upper sequence and brings back to Digit, and that's the mode in which B/S is invoked; however that is paradoxical since B/S does not appear in the codes of Digit mode; and requires to treat B/S as a character, while the _character set_ is defined as "all 8-bit values" plus "two non-data characters" (FNC1 and ECI), which does not include B/S. The only thing weakly in support of ZXing's interpretation is that annex H, table LatLen, counts 14 bits to go from Digit to Binary _and back_ including 5-bit length (when that would require 19 bits per the above literal interpretation). However annex H similarly miscounts how many bits it takes to go from Punctuation to Binary and back (as 15 bits rather than the unambiguous 20 bits); is a general mess; and is informative only, thus can not override normative parts of the standard. The problem is fixed (with no negative side effect, I hope) by inserting between the two lines 133/134 of [core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/aztec/decoder/Decoder.java](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/blob/master/core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/aztec/decoder/Decoder.java#L133) currently reading Of course a test case should be added in [core/src/test/resources/blackbox/aztec-1](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/tree/master/core/src/test/resources/blackbox/aztec-1), with dlusbs.png and the expected dlusbs.txt, as enclosed in this zip: [dlusbs.zip](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/files/394203/dlusbs.zip) The problem was detected by encoding test input 3333h3i3j33333 with a tentative direct implementation of the encoding algorithm in annex H, written on the assumption that it is optimal (it's stated goal) at least in the case of letters and digits. Decoding worked fine with ZXing, not with NeoReader. The root cause of the issue seems to be the messy annex H and ZXing's implementation of the decoder.

Sure, sounds like you have looked into this thoroughly! thank you. Feel free to open a pull request with your change so we can test it (ideally with your test case thrown in). If it all passes, I'll merge it.

Hello,

I don't know whether the following issue is due to your website image reader or due to your zxing library.
There is no impressum and no contact on your [website](https://zxing.org/w/decode.jspx) so I put the issue here.

When uploading a **plain PBM** image and there's no whitespace in the pbm's raster section, the website will prompt:

> **No Barcode Found**
> No barcode was found in this image. Either it did not contain a barcode, or did not contain one in a supported format, or the software was simply unable to find it. Go "Back" in your browser and try another image.

The [plain PBM specification](http://netpbm.sourceforge.net/doc/pbm.html) states:
- Each pixel in the raster is represented by a byte containing ASCII '1' or '0', representing black and white respectively.
- White space in the raster section is ignored.

In example gimp omits the spaces between the entries when an image is exported as pbm(ascii).
In the zip archive only file foobar2.pbm (with spaces inbetween) works and produces "foobar".

[foobar.zip](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/files/380395/foobar.zip)

It is just using Java's ImageIO to read images, so whatever that library supports is what it reads. I have not heard of PBM; it looks like some kind of an _ASCII_ format for encoding monochrome images? I'm not sure that's worth supporting.

We tried to encode the following sample data string: 

`JGB<Space>012000001200000042LL139TY2J09TY2J0<Space><Space><Space><Space><Space><Space><Space><Space><Space><Space><Space><Space><Space>` (where `<space>` represents an actual single space character)

to a DataMatrix barcode with the following hints:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Resulting barcode: ![blob](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7415007/16592568/06f6ac28-42ea-11e6-85e7-23c35e433813.png)

It reads no problem, but our partner's system does not accept it, claiming that in the raw barcode data, right after `JCB`, there is a service character code 254 (`FE`) that ends the C40 encoding mode, and C40 mode is only reentered after `LL13`, whereas their system has a strict requirement for the C40 mode to be used throughout the entire barcode. The 24x24 size is also a strict requirement of theirs.

Indeed, raw barcode data, as reported by the ZXing online decoder, seems to match what they are saying:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

`e6` at offset 0 starts C40, then there is `fe` at offset 3, then there is another `e6` at offset 17.

We believe this is not expected behaviour, or is it?

I'm not an expert on Data Matrix enough to say for sure, but, I don't think a particular mode is mandatory throughout the barcode. It can legally latch to whatever mode it likes. Some choices are more efficient than others, but many are legal. You could hack the code to never choose anything but C40 but I don't think that's somehow required by the format.

Okay then, if that is the case, the issue turns out to be a feature request rather than a bug report, at which point I will have to look into hacking the code.

Regarding the requirement, it's the UK Royal Mail, they want a [MailMark barcode](http://www.royalmail.com/mailmark/technical) on letters (which is a DataMatrix ECC200 barcode), and they absolutely want C40 throughout. They require applicants to submit sample barcodes and they run them through an automated testing process that results in a pretty impressively looking report that details every possible physical property of the barcode and rates each one. Not having C40 throughout comes out as a stopper issue on this report, so we can't apply with our barcodes, which means mailing will be more expensive for us.

Apparently this is by design, all DataMatrix encoders peek into the future characters, and if they see that it would be more compact to encode them with a different encoding mode, they request to change themselves to a different encoder before proceeding.

I might have patched this, but I'm not sure if it's worth a pull request. If it is, I'm not sure what would be a better way to do it!

One way is to convert `C40Encoder` into an abstract class `C40EncoderBase` with a protected abstract property `peekAllowed`, and make two derived classes, `C40Encoder` that overrides the property to `true` and `MailMarkEncoder` that overrides it to `false`. `C40EncoderBase` would check this property before calling `HighLevelEncoder.lookAheadTest`.
That way we have a full blown new encoder (which is 99.9% `C40Encoder`), and we'll need to add `static final int MAILMARK_ENCODATION = 6;` to `HighLevelEncoder` and otherwise teach it to recognize the new constant.

Another way would be adding the `peekAllowed` flag to the `EncoderContext` and teach `C40Encoder` to respect it. That way we don't create a separate encoder, we introduce a new encoding hint instead. It will be visible to all other encoders, which might be a good thing or not, I don't know enough about this to tell if it's safe for other types of encoders to not request encoding change like it is safe for `C40`.

## Contributing

The project is in maintenance mode, meaning, changes are driven by contributed patches.
There is otherwise no active development or roadmap for this project. It is "DIY".

Only proposed changes in the form of a pull request are likely to be acted on, but,
these will be acted on promptly.
###  Questions

Questions should be asked on the mailing list:
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/zxing
### Feature Requests

Feature requests are not accepted and will generally be closed.
Feature requests with a pull request may be accepted. When in doubt, discuss on the
mailing list first.
### Bug Reports

Bug reports must have enough detail to understand and reproduce the problem. Inadequate
bug reports will be closed with a request for more information.

Bug reports without an associated pull request are not likely to be addressed, but will be
left open for some time to see if anyone can contribute a solution. However, bug reports
with a pull request are likely to be merged promptly.

I'm not sure what you're referring to, but if you're proposing a change to the code, describe it in a pull request.

This pull request improves efficiency of DataMatrix detector in TRY_HARDER mode. Using existing image sets the DataMatrixBlackBox2TestCase decodes 6 more images in 0 degrees rotation, 1 more in 180 degrees rotation and 1 more in 270 degrees rotation.

The main motivation for the proposed changes was the poor decode results of DataMatrix reader having as input scanned images that contain DataMatrix barcodes. We had large sets of scanned images that have little distortion caused by the scanner or pencil lines by humans on the barcode. In this version we can read images like the following:

![cropimage1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3668016/16297307/cc3086dc-391f-11e6-8c81-590fb0223357.jpg)

![githubimage2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3668016/16297348/0894327c-3920-11e6-9e2b-e135b83cba78.jpg)

The main enhancements in detector algorithm are the following:
1.We don’t need to correct TopRight edge point, the edges are computed correctly from the beginning thus the initial computation of dimension does not need correction.
2.In order to compute transitions we sample more segments, moving edge points in proper direction. The final result is the most popular transition among samples.
3.To compute edge points in a rectangle we enhance the existing algorithm that uses getBlackPointOnSegment() with two more segments. The one moves on horizontal axis at double speed, and the other moves on vertical axis at double speed. Finally, we combine the results to compute the edge point.
4.We introduce tolerance in WhiteRectangleDetector. The result is that the algorithm is more efficient in low quality images with distortion. 
5.We enhance the calculation of transitions of a segment with a validation algorithm that compares each transition length to the length of the most popular transition. If a length is too small (probably sign of distortion of human interpolation) we investigate the problematic area and if find proofs of distortion we correct the calculation of transition.
Finally, there are no changes in algorithm in normal mode (that does not uses TRY_HARDER hint).

Generally that's a good improvement. It is a lot of added code and much of it duplicated. I wonder if it can be refactored? There are also a fair number of variations from the standard Java style of the rest of the code, like spaces around braces and so on.

I refactored code to remove duplication. For style issue it would be helpful to add check style constraints to better understand at build time the code that does not mach with the rest. Otherwise, could you show me a sample line and I will refactor the rest.
OK, I made some additional changes to the checkstyle config that will flag the whitespace changes among other things. I'll look at the rest.
Hm, I'm conflicted about this. The performance improvement is good though it will not affect regular scanning use cases. It's a fair bit of extra code complexity even now though.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Obviously barcodes will never exist in files that have 1 pixel, but zxing should not crash for it. (I'm running it on a lot of files, and this happened to be one of them)

The issue is that `localLuminance` in [GlobalHistogramBinarizer](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/blob/b189fd1d5629770b1ecbdf3e2f55a37776538957/core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/common/GlobalHistogramBinarizer.java#L71) directly accesses the 2nd element (which does not exist).

Added some refactoring to the BitMatrix.java class

Hm, I think this is a lot of change and some may not be worth it. For example 32 is so clearly understood as bits in an int and can never change, so not sure it helps to make it a constant. The name would be all caps anyway and I don't think it is a maximum number of bits. I also understand expanding pos to position but I don't think it adds readability net net. There are some indentation issues and some accidentally changed javadoc I think. BitRegion is interesting but it requires making an object every time methods like this are called internally and I think that adds nontrivial overhead for not much readability gain. Maybe there is another way to do that without object creation, to at least factor out at checking. As it is I would prefer not to make these changes.

When dealing with Ethernet/IP network we deal with erasures instead of errors. We know which packets are missing so RS error correcting capability is increased by giving its position. Therefore, 1 parity symbol can recover from one erasure instead of 2 symbols for one error. I have an idea you must know all these details. Just wondering why there isn't any thing in the docs regarding passing error position to rs decoder so that its error correcting capability can be increased. Ior is there a way to tackle with erasures instead of errors in zxing?
The error correction routines do support erasures and errors. You'd have to read the implementation to see how it works though. This isn't an issue report, so I'm closing it.

For a web app I'm working on I am experimenting with adding support for scanning bar codes with the [scan from web](https://github.com/zxing/zxing/wiki/Scanning-From-Web-Pages) option using the zxing URI scheme. Depending on where in the web app the user decides to create a new item, a link like https://example.com/items/new?stuff_id=123 is generated so that certain fields can be prepopulated with 'stuff' data.

In order to not lose the prepopulated data, I included the query string in the return URL like this `zxing://scan/?ret=https://example.com/items/new?barcode=%7BCODE%7D&stuff_id=123` but after scanning I'm redirected to `https://example.com/items/new?barcode=9988776655` - the prepopulated 'stuff' fields are now empty.

My app caught the following exception while scanning a barcode with zxing-core 3.2.1:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Do you have a reproduction for this? I get reports like this already but never have an image to reproduce. Usually I assume it's a bad driver sending back the wrong size image. If it _never_ works for you, then that's probably it. If it _sometimes_ fails for you, it's almost certainly some corner case in the app.

This is the first time I've seen this crash in hundreds of scans on half a dozen devices. Is there some check I can perform on the preview frame before constructing the binarizer to check whether the data's valid?

I copied the loop code from HybridBinarizer and changed the array reference into a simple check for the index being less than height \* width.  It worked for all sizes where 8 <= height < 1000 and 8 <= width < 1000.  I suspect the bug is a corner case in the driver.

@tanelihuuskonen thanks for checking this out! I agree that a corner case in the driver is likely as I've never run into this exception before or since. What checks should I perform on the preview frame received from the camera to validate it before passing it into the QRCodeReader? Or would it be better to make no assumptions about the preview frame and just catch the exception in the rare case that the frame is invalid?

Yeah, I mean obviously the problem is that the expected size of the image doesn't match the actual size of the data from the driver. I'm sure that's the proximate cause already, but the question is why. I have seen this happen in the past when the driver fails to init: you ask for preview size X x Y and it fails to take that config, and you get some default (much smaller) size back.

That is, I think it would fail never or always. It's not something intermittent -- I think. I'd be super surprised.

The app calls camera.getParameters().getPreviewSize() in the onPreviewFrame() callback, and uses the resulting width and height to create the decoder, but I guess the parameters may change between the time the preview frame is generated and the time it's delivered to the PreviewCallback, so the data may correspond to a different preview size.
I don't (yet) see how it changes though. It should be set correctly once at the outset.

@akwizgran To avoid the index out of bounds exception, you should make sure the length of the data array is at least the height times the width of the image before calling the constructor of a luminance source.  I'm afraid I don't know enough about camera drivers to suggest a proper fix for the underlying problem.

@srowen This pull request resolves a race condition seen in printing output in the command line runner. I'm not entirely sure why this occurs, but presumably the multithreaded execution of the command line runner can cause the `println` calls to be executed out of order. This is apparently something that [can happen with println in multithreaded execution](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19460987/why-is-system-out-prinln-out-of-order).

I found this occurs in two cases in my OS X environment. The first was when one of the input files is a symlink to another of input files. The second was when the files had very recently been written to disk by another program. I'm guessing in both cases, the data is already in memory, making the race condition more likely. The goofy output looks like this:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Note that the points from the first file were printed while printing the points from the second file.

In order to avoid the race condition, I wrote the output using a `StringWriter` for each file, printing the output for each file when it's ready. My understanding is that `System.out.println` synchronizes the output buffer, so this should be a safe operation.

I noticed the following when doing some testing of the zxing library. The image below contains a UPC-A barcode and a QR code, but when the `CommandLineRunner` is run with `--multi --try_harder`, it finds a spurious EAN 8 barcode. I'm guessing this is because part of the barcode is creased and UPC-A and EAN-8 use the same encoding. It presumably picks up the creased UPC-A barcode "part way through", finding something like an EAN-8 encoding.

Please free to close this issue as "won't fix". The issue isn't likely to cause many problems in practice, and `--try_harder` is a mode which I presume is prone to false positives. My hope was that you might be interested in a tricky false positive example to add to your collection of test cases if a fix is possible.

Thanks for all your work on this excellent library!
## How to reproduce

Note that only the QR code is found without `--try_harder`.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>
## Output

<S_CODE_TOKEN>
## Expected output

Same as above, but without the EAN_8 barcode.
## System information

OS X El Capitan 10.11.2.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>
## Image

![batteries](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/123110/12871393/de032b9e-cd2c-11e5-890a-bafca3285256.jpg)

Yeah, a false positive is always possible. Given enough pixels, something will look 'close enough' to a barcode. Indeed the whole library is a heuristic. How much like a barcode does every stretch of pixels look like? there's always threshold and rules to balance finding a real barcode vs not finding phantoms.

I am sure you can find images that consistently reproduce a false positive since decoding is deterministic. You could add this to the test suite, add changes or tunings that make it succeed, and then see how many other test images fail or succeed. If you find a setting that's net positive, I'd be happy to commit that. Otherwise, yeah this is just how it is.

Alright. If I get a better understanding of the code working with the library further, I'll look in to submitting a patch with this as a test case.

Thanks again for your work on this library!

This is the post on reddit that is linked to in the verge article I linked earlier.

[–]etalvala 53 points  3 months ago  Hi - Tech lead for Android's camera framework here.Image sensors on a compliant Android device can be mounted in one of two ways. Most devices use one way, so a lot of camera apps have never been tested on devices that pick the other way.Because of manufacturing reasons, we needed to mount the Nexus 5X main sensor in the less-common (reverse landscape) orientation - the wires from the sensor chip wouldn't have fit otherwise.Unfortunately, our old camera API (which is deprecated, but most apps still use it) isn't terribly user-friendly, and requires application developers to explicitly set the preview rotation. On most devices, though, it turns out the default rotation is correct for a forced-landscape app, so many apps never call the display orientation method.The new camera2 API handles the rotation automatically for developers, but until they move to the new API, apps need to use the boilerplate we have in the developer docs to check the sensor and UI orientation, and apply the right rotation: http://developer.android.com/reference/android/hardware/Camera.html#setDisplayOrientation(int)We tried to work out a way to adjust the default so that apps wouldn't have to deal with this, but unfortunately changing it would have broken apps that do call this method.This is also why a number of apps showed upside down preview on the Nexus 6 front-facing camera last year - it's also in the less-common orientation. But far fewer apps support the front-facing camera than the back-facing one, so it was less of an issue than it is for Nexus 5X.So if you do see apps with upside-down camera preview on Nexus 5X, please let the developers know about this - Android's developer relations folks are trying to reach out to apps as we find them, and LG is also helping out, but it might take a bit before everyone's up to speed on this issue.

A bug exists in the way zxing calculates the mask to apply during QR code generation.

Eight masks have to be tested and the one with the lowest penalty is chosen to be applied to the QR code being created. Each mask is scored on four criteria (rules), and rule 3 gives a penalty based on a particular sequence of black and white squares being present in the code. 

zxing uses two helper functions `isWhiteHorizontal` and `isWhiteVertical`  to test if a given range of cells are all white (=0). 

However, a bug in the functions makes them return `true` even if the range of cells is out of range. This results often in higher rule 3 penalty values and can end up with a QR code choosing a suboptimal masking pattern.

I haven't read the code in a while, but I believe the assumption is that anything outside the QR code's boundary is white. This seems to implement that correctly. Is this wrong according to the spec? could be, I haven't looked at this in ages.

This could be written more simply I think if so, by checking the range upfront rather than in the loop.
Perhaps... not clear in the official specification what is considered "existance of the pattern in the symbol".  So best to leave as is then due to lack of certainty.   Thanks
Yeah, I'm not entirely sure either, but if there's evidence that the interpretation should change, that's fine. As you can see it makes some tests fail, but the tests could be wrong.

Hi;

I have a rare problem.
Our company have Code 39 barcodes, with black bars on the red background. ZXing barcode scanner can't read properly this barcodes, somtimes it takes 20 seconds, but reading OK for standart b/w barcodes, it reads in 1-2 second(s).

Is there any way to solve/hack this problem? Any configuration, suggestion or similar thing?

I think you just want to map your images to black-and-white first. If you know color = white, then you can easily write a transformation from YUV space that boosts "Y" (brightness) to the extent that U differs from V (U = V means no color).

I would do this in the library, except that in some cases, people have a color-on-white barcodes for example and so the opposite is desirable. Hm, if you have good success in developing this transform, maybe we could add them both as helper functions for `BufferedImage`s?

The library is not able to scan some code39 barcodes with check digit.
I did the test with different barcodes.
- when the barcode ends with - or . checkdigit, it works
- when the barcode ends with $, %, + checkdigit, it doesn't work.

I think the problem is related to the calculation of the check digit (total variable) where we use the ALPHABET_STRING tab which contains the \* (star) character whereas the specification doesn't include this star character as part of the possible check digit (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Code_39)

2D-Doc is a specific usage of Datamatrix defined in France, see [1] for more information.

There is no issue to read 2D-Doc with zxing.

The only issue is about generation because 2D-Doc only uses ASCII encoding and does not optimize the encoding.

This patch:
- modify HighLevelEncoder to allow bypass of encodation optimization
- provide a new specific writer: DDDocWriter
- provide a 2D-Doc encoder
- provide some local changes to glue all the stuff

This is my first attempt with zxing, so I am waiting for your feedbacks to improve this proposal.

KR,
Guillaume

[1] https://ants.gouv.fr/content/download/516/5665/version/4/file/ANTS_2D-Doc_CABSpec_v2.0.1_erratum.pdf
in french, sorry
Hm, my concern here is just about adding code to support a very niche format. It's not much, but also I am not clear how much this is used if ever.

I agree that this format looks niche right now. The interest in France is growing but not so quickly. According to the french gov service in charge of this format, there is some interest on that in Germany, but I would not give any value to that information.

My first attempt was to only extend the existing DatamatrixWriter but the way HighLevelEncoder is done blocked  me.

Maybe a better idea would be to propose some rework on HighLevelEncoder to make it more configurable and make specific encoder injection possible.

What do you think ?

To my understanding, I still kinda reject this explanation. Regardless of physical orientation, opening the camera with defaults and flinging the data onto the screen should produce the intuitive result. The image data at the right of the device should be at the right of the screen, etc.

I found this article in the Android Developer Google+ Page that seems relevant:

Unfortunately, you have to deal with this in the scanner app, as we discussed earlier this year (https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/zxing/JqIGVBUXup0).

Yes, the API's pretty stupid here. It's one of the things we've fixed in the camera2 API. 

The old camera API has no connection to the UI framework or to the display metrics, so it has no ability to automatically rotate the preview to be the right way up; you have to call setDisplayOrientation() accordingly, the developer docs have sample code: http://developer.android.com/reference/android/hardware/Camera.html#setDisplayOrientation(int)

In the past, for forced-landscape apps, the default value of '0' is the correct value most of the time - that's what devices with main sensors that are landscape end up needing.  And portrait-mode apps need '90'. But the Android compatibility requirements also allow for reverse-landscape sensor orientation, which needs '180' and '270' for those two states, respectively.

OK, I know I have indeed had to build around this in the past and I feel like I forget all this and re-learn it about once a year ... probably better to just dig out the code and try to address this than answer emails.

On the one hand, I get surprised that this behavior is even possible: would you ever want the image entering at the part of the lens closest to the top of the display not render at the top of the display? this doesn't depend on the orientation of the device or how it's mounted. Aside from enabling goofy effects, it seems like a degree of freedom that's unnecessary.

Then again you may want to receive image data in the app in a different orientation than the camera is physically seeing it, because the device has gone into portrait or landscape UI mode. But then, that's a separate question from how the preview surface displays.

I suppose my question boils down to ... why would the physical orientation of the sensor matter? from an API perspective it should be relative to the UI. But I guess that's what you're saying. Couple that with the fact that virtually all Android devices happen to work out this way and yeah it seems a little problematic to create a device that ends up with this different behavior.

The compatibility requirements need the sensor long edge to line up with the long edge of the device, and the native orientation of phones is portrait.  And sensors generally are landscape-oriented themselves (though not all, there are at least some square ones out there).

So it's basically never the case for a phone that the sensor top-left matches the native screen top-left.  But generally the forced-landscape top-left has indeed lined up with the sensor top-left. Of course, on larger tablets which are often native landscape, the sensors do line up.

And the math is a pain, which is why we have that boilerplate code (and why we made sure you don't have to deal with it in the new API), and the boilerplate math should do the right thing on all form factors, UI orientations, and camera facings.

You're probably seeing problems with a fast 180-degree rotation. (if you go slow and let it do two 90-degree rotations, it's likely fine).  That's yet another quirk of the UI system - it doesn't reconfig for a 180-degree change since it doesn't change any metrics.  But of course, it's important for a camera app on the old camera API to know to update the preview orientation.

I think the solution is to listen to the raw orientation sensor events to catch that happening, but I'll have to check on that.

That's normal in that the app will choose a suitable preview size that best matches the aspect ratio of the screen. But, devices don't always provide a lot of choices. In this case it looks like the preview size with sufficient resolution doesn't match the aspect ratio so it renders as stretched. It's just a cosmetic effect. You can see the logic for picking the preview size in the project here. I'm open to suggestions about changing it, but it's generally robust across devices at this stage.

Hello, I'm not sure if this is an issue on my side, or a feature request.

Would it be possible for you to support extended ISSN barcodes? It is an EAN-13 code with extra digits used for added information like issue number: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Standard_Serial_Number.

Example http://www.free-barcode-generator.net/issn/ - and try example 9772434561006:12001. As I tried the extended characters aren't recognized only the main EAN-13 part.

It already reads both the EAN 13 and the extension. It appears to be the same encoding as the "+2" or "+5" extension for UPC/EAN used elsewhere. Note that the extension is not considered part of the barcode and is returned separately as metadata. It's also not going to fail the decode if it sees the EAN but can't read the extension.

The specification says that a leading FNC1-character is used to identify GS1 barcodes, and should be decoded as "]d2" (GS1 DataMatrix), "]C1" (GS1-128), "]e0" (GS1 DataBar Omnidirectional) or "]Q3" (GS1 QR Code). Any other occurrences of FNC1-characters should be decoded as ASCII GS-characters (byte value 29).  I managed to get FNC1-characters for DataMatrix, QR Code and GS1-128, but cannot do the same for DataBar because I don't have idea where to look at.

Actually, I think that if you tell JCommander that the type is an enum type like ErrorCorrectionLevel, it will know to parse the string value of the flag as an enum for you. Some barcode generators (e.g. Okapi) seem to generate additional barcode
rows at the end of the barcode, which can be decoded as valid barcode
rows, but actually contain garbage. The barcode metadata states that
these additional rows are not part of the barcode. So we ignore those
addional rows when parsing the barcode. This could potentially also
happen (though quite unlikely) if data after the barcode looks like a
barcode row.

Interesting, if it doesn't break detection of any existing barcodes, and doesn't introduce significantly false positives (highly unlikely) then this could be a good change. The following PDF417 bar code, which was generated using [Okapi](https://github.com/woo-j/OkapiBarcode/) and encodes the text _"This is just a test."_ cannot be decoded by ZXing:

![normal-basic-6-rows-6-columns](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/178883/9533715/ef3d587e-4ce1-11e5-94bb-98def8edb995.png)

It decodes without any issues with a hardware bar code scanner.

I would attach a stack trace, but it throws a `FormatException` without a stack trace (at `DetectionResultRowIndicatorColumn#125`, in the `getRowHeights()` method).

The metadata cointained in the generated barcode does not match the actual barcode. According to the barcode metadata, the barcode is supposed to consist of 4 rows, but it actually consists of 6 rows. The last two rows of the barcode contain garbage. If I ignore the last two rows, the code decodes properly as "This is just a test.". I suggest you report this problem to Okapi.
If you cannot fix Okapi right away, you can apply the following to xing, which will cause it to ignore the additional garbage rows. 

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Nice analysis, thanks @graug . If it's a problem in the generator, then yes that's the place to take it up, unless someone can argue that the decoder is supposed to handle this situation. In the meantime yes that's a decent hack you could apply.

Thx @srowen . In this case the problem is the generator, but it could potentially happen (though very unlikely) that the zxing decoder erroneously detects additional rows after the actual barcode rows. I don't have a PDF417 spec, so I don't know how the decoder is supposed to handle this case. If we abide by the general rules for communication, we should be very strict in what we generate, but lenient in what we accept. So I guess we should probably accept the presented barcode and decode it, despite the garbage at the end. I've created a pull request.

Hm, I'd hope it doesn't make a difference as it looks like you have enough quiet zone around the ends, regardless. Maybe not at the right end; that's worth measuring. If you mean it works after you crop the image, then that's probably it.

Yes, I think you could, in this case, consider any color as white-ness. If converting from YUV, you'd add chroma to the luminance or something. In this particular case, yeah you could boost the amount of red that contributes to perceived luminance so that red comes out white.

/common/reedsolomon/ZXGenericGF.m:(Line 41)
common/reedsolomon/ZXGenericGF.m:(Line 40)
common/ZXHybridBinarizer.m:(Line 59)
common/ZXHybridBinarizer.m:(Line 150)

pdf417/decoder/ec/ZXModulusGF.m:(Line 46)
pdf417/decoder/ec/ZXModulusGF.m:(Line 47)
core/ZXPlanarYUVLuminanceSource.m:(Line 114)

Impact:
This may lead to a memory crash enabling attackers to gain access
Recommendation:

If a function can return an error code or any other evidence of its success or failure, always check for the error condition, even if there is no obvious way for it to occur. In addition to preventing security errors, many initially mysterious bugs have eventually led back to a failed system call with an ignored return value.
This code is not from this project

Hello,
Our security team has identified potential security issues:

ZXAztecReader.m:(Line 71)
ZXAztecReader.m:(Line 65)

Impact:
Most null pointer issues result in general software reliability problems, but if an attacker can intentionally trigger a null pointer dereference, the attacker might be able to use the resulting exception to bypass security logic or to cause the application to reveal debugging information that will be valuable in planning subsequent attacks.

Recommendation:
Implement careful checks before dereferencing objects that might be null. When possible, abstract null checks into wrappers around code that manipulates resources to ensure that they are applied in all cases and to minimize the places where mistakes can occur.
Also not in this project

So, it's not always clear what 'raw bytes' should return since some barcodes have nothing that might be called an underlying byte representation. For some, like this or QR codes there are several layers: raw code words, after error correction is parsed, after the bit stream is parsed, after the bytes are parsed as characters. For QR codes I use the result post error correction. My theory is people don't really want to also do the error correction by hand, but may want to access the raw encoding from that point after. so I'd provisionally close this as working as intended. If needed you can hack the code to do most anything you need.

Hi proCoderDude,

as far as I can tell, the barcode is flipped vertically, i.e. it starts with row 33 and ends with row 0. The decoder assumes that the barcode correctly starts with row 0. I flipped the image and managed to decode it, although the content doesn't seem to be readable text.

![pdf417-flipped](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4060134/8786268/690d66da-2f2d-11e5-9cfa-0db532c4230b.png)

Best regards,

  Guenther

I am doing the generation asynchronous to the creation of db entry, but I need to know if the data are valid before the encoding proces.
You can simply catch for exceptions. There is a well-defined exception hierarchy for this. It doesn't require an API change, works for all the encoders, and is the intended way to check this.

I think it is not really effective to call encode only for the information that the contents are invalid. See pseudocode of your suggestion:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Example case described: Scheduling of object to queue contains its id, code and format. Processing of object means encoding the contents **again**, creating a image and upload to amazon s3 for example. In the moment of processing the exception cannot be proceeded to the user.
Sending Bitmatrix instead of code and format would be inefective - its bigger and the bitmatrix is not needed yet.
Besides that, it would separate the knowledge of _contents validity_ from the _bitmatrix creation_ itself and enhance the code quality.
I still think this is a valid request for enhancement.

Why do you have to process it twice? It either succeeds or fails in one pass.

I suppose my point is the act of deciding whether it's encodable often means executing some or most of the encoding process anyway; there's not much to save. Creating an 'encodable' API is mostly recreating the whole encoding process anyway, to be really sure. The encoding process is also generally very fast, so I think it's not worth worrying about.

Yeah, I mean, that's an artifact of how your system works though; in general you can invoke the method once and either get a result or know it could not encode. Honestly it is not worrying about optimizing this by exposing this logic. Having to call the method twice is so cheap. This stuff was written to be efficient on _phones_ even as of 8 years ago. Server-class machines would do this in microseconds.

- fine-grained scaling for PDF_417 generation

That's probably OK. You likely know this code better than I. Is the effect just that it scales the result from 1-pixel bars rather than always starting at 2? that seems reasonable.

Is there a reason to start the PDF_417 generation with a lineThickness of 2 [1] if the barcode is later scalled [2]. This excludes the generation of barcodes with lineThickness of 3 for example.

[1] https://github.com/zxing/zxing/blob/master/core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/pdf417/PDF417Writer.java#L100
[2] https://github.com/zxing/zxing/blob/master/core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/pdf417/PDF417Writer.java#L121
I dont' think I get the question (didn't write this code either) but if you can show and explain a change in a PR I can look at it.
The current generation starts with lineThickness 2 and scales the barcode later to fit into the available space. This prevents for example the generation of a barcode with scale factor 1,3,5 etc.

(This isn't the place for questions -- use the mailing list). Probably a false positive read of a finder pattern. Use pure-barcode mode.
I didn't ask any questions. I was reporting a bug and how to recreate the bug. Surely if failing to read an image of a qrcode that the api creates while other ones do is a bug.

Really, I mean that this is only for proposing patches / pull requests. It will work just like the online decoder if you make it work like the online decoder, and you can look at the source for it. But I'm pretty sure it's that it passes with PURE_BARCODE mode which you aren't trying here.
So you are saying that it is not a bug that the api cannot detect a barcode is an image of a pure barcode?

The problem is that, weirdly, it becomes exceptionally easy to mis-detect a finder pattern in such a barcode. Once those are found incorrectly the rest fails. The heuristics that work exceptionally well in a photo or camera frame have this weakness on a synthetic image, but this is optimizing for camera phones not pure images. Still it's easy to get it right and much faster if you know it's supposed to be a synthetic image, so there's a hint for this. You should use it if you know the image is synthetic since it will be faster too. You can always try it as a fallback, like the online decoder does.

Not sure what you mean that the API can't detect it. You are using the online decoder, which uses the API, which detects it as you say.
OK, personally I would describe this as a bug but I can see why you do not. Sorry for wasting your time

For an international number - like +4935100000000 - the meCard doesn't include the required "+". The number will be encoded without and can't be dialed. Using vCard ist working fine.
You haven't specified how you are encoding this value or what the result is.

@srowen I used the webbased encoding at https://zxing.appspot.com/generator, selected "contact information" encoded as "meCard". I put "+4935100000000" into the phone number field. 

The result is lacking the "+" sign for international prefix: 

MECARD:N:meCard;TEL:4935100000000;;

http://zxing.org/w/chart?cht=qr&chs=350x350&chld=L&choe=UTF-8&chl=MECARD%3AN%3AmeCard%3BTEL%3A4935100000000%3B%3B

If I encode as vCard, its working fine:

BEGIN:VCARD
VERSION:3.0
N:meCard
TEL:+4935100000000
END:VCARD 

http://zxing.org/w/chart?cht=qr&chs=350x350&chld=L&choe=UTF-8&chl=BEGIN%3AVCARD%0AVERSION%3A3.0%0AN%3AmeCard%0ATEL%3A%2B4935100000000%0AEND%3AVCARD
MECARD format says this field is digits-only. You need to write + as 00. https://www.nttdocomo.co.jp/english/service/developer/make/content/barcode/function/application/addressbook/index.html

"00" is only correct for some countries. Only "+" qualifies as international prefix. If you save your number with "00" as international number, you won't be able to dial it many countries in the world. Have a look here:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_international_call_prefixes

So meCard standard has a blind spot here. However almost all soft phones and smart phones are capable of handling the "+" sign.
Yeah that may be, but that's a MECARD issue if anything. It was originally created in the 90s for i-mode in Japan so may not be entirely internationalized. You can use vCard instead.

You are right, technically that is absolutely the correct answer.
If MECARD "standard" is not maintained anymore, maybe a not so strict implementation might be helpful?
Yeah, I think that's not unreasonable. Do you want to make a patch that would allow this character?

If I could, but I'm not a programmer :(

Alright, I've fixed my problem (QR-encoding String to a Bitmap in Android) by looking at the android/src/com/google/zxing/client/android/encode/QRCodeEncoder.java:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

The resulting screenshot and more details can be seen in [my Stackoverflow question](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/30515584/qr-encode-a-string-to-image-in-android-project-using-zxing).

This allows page titles with HTML entities like `&` to display properly. Before, no decoding would be performed and `&` would be shown where an ampersand should be. Additionally, decoding entities prevents the following string length check from overcounting.

To replicate this bug scan an image with a URL pointing to http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/android The title displayed within the app will be something like: `Frequent 'android' Questions - Stack Overflow` After this commit, the app will display the correct decoded title: `Frequent 'android' Questions - Stack Overflow`

Alternatively, scan this to replicate:
![http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/android](http://zxing.org/w/chart?cht=qr&chs=120x120&chld=L&choe=UTF-8&chl=http%3A%2F%2Fstackoverflow.com%2Fquestions%2Ftagged%2Fandroid)

T

I don't think this is representative of images presented to a phone, so I'm not worried about it. The issue is that one corner of the DM code is always missing, and if you look for a corner on the side that ends in a white module you find the edge of its neighboring black modules. That almost always doesn't make a difference, as you count across the modules to the other corners to identify the number of black-white transitions and figure out the dimension of the barcode. After that it's pretty easy. But in this case the modules are too relatively large, and the line drawn across the modules misses several transitions. It's hard to know a priori how to correct for that.

You can try the PURE_BARCODE mode but I don't think it will work on this image.
