Perhaps in the next major version you could add a prefix to the maven artifact names so that the jars get a decent name in non-library upstream projects (ie WAR)?

Right now the jars will have the nondescript and confusing names of `core-x.x.x.jar` and `javase-x.x.x.jar` in a canonical Maven WAR. The ostensible industry standard seems to be to prefix your artifact names with the project name.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

There are of course work-arounds (such as never name any of your artifacts `core` or configure: http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-war-plugin/examples/file-name-mapping.html )  so I understand if this bug/encancement is considered trivial or not really worth doing.

No, I don't think it's good to change the artifact names at this point, for continuity. The `groupId` already names the project, so I don't think there's a strong need to repeat it in the `artifactId`. Yeah I see a lot of this repetition but since an `artifactId` is never used in isolation in a build it doesn't matter. It does affect the name of generated artifacts, but those can be overridden where needed. But even things like the war name seem OK to me.

Well I agree on the continuity but not on consistency given that zxing child modules have a parent module called... `zxing-parent`. Apparently `parent` was too abstract :)

Given that you don't seem to care about the artifact name I'm not sure what the continuity buys you given that major revisions are generally not drop in replacement upgrades. Many google and non google projects have changed artifact and even organization names. It is only annoying on minor versions.

I have also yet to see any other project that doesn't have some sort of descriptive artifact name (prefix or not). I have also yet to see a project that makes sure to generate jars with the groupId prefixed (this includes the Spark project which you recently did some build stuff for). Imagine if everyone just named their artifacts "core" (luckily spark is spark-core).

I would have perfectly accepted the answer.. "its not worth the time" but I'm not sure I buy the continuity or lets be clever and DRY :)

I agree about `zxing-parent`. I know you're talking about a major version upgrade, though honestly there will likely never be a 4.x, so this is moot. If there ever is 4.x it should be mostly compatible anyway. An entirely new project in a different namespace does probably deserve new artifacts, yes, but that will never be the case in this project.

I think you're overlooking a problem with changing artifact names: Maven can't resolve conflict between two versions. If I depend on Foo and Bar, and Foo depends on old-artifact and Bar depends on new-artifact, then I get two conflicting copies of the same library, but Maven can't know that. This won't work if the versions still share namespaces. The down-stream project manually sorts it out with excludes. Similarly if you need to support using both the old and new version in a build, your only option is to use Maven profiles and have to enable one or the other in a build command line, rather than manage it with a version property, because you're having to add / omit entire dependencies selectively, not just change a version. Maven makes this a lot harder.

I don't have anything against `zxing-core` and might even pick that over `core` today, but the naming doesn't cause any problem in Maven. Are you just worried about the name of the resulting artifacts? these only matter if they're being consumed directly outside Maven for some reason and can be overridden as needed. For example, the `.apk` products don't take on names like `android`.

I don't understand your last sentence, but this isn't a matter of 'not having time'. Changing this is not a good idea in the foreseeable lifetime of this project, which is why I closed this.

Yes I think I agree with you especially now that I know the project isn't changing drastically for some time.

And I am aware of the Maven issue and it is an excellent point. I was thinking major revision + plus namespace change like Jackson or commons lang 3 did but I realize that there are a plethora of projects that don't  do namespace changes on major revisions for many of the reasons you mentioned.

As for the name conflict it appears it is plugin dependent. I have seen an older Maven WAR plugin have problems with duplicate artifact names but this was many many years ago. I'm not sure exactly sure if they fixed it as I haven't had two projects with the exact same artifact name.

I frequently look at the jars that are packaged with my WAR (along with the maven dependency tree) and I always have a double take / WTF is this jar and have to go click on it or `unzip -l` to figure out what it is.

Looking back I think I misinterpreted your original reply and I think it is good the bug is closed.

Test Name: splitQuery Unit Test Version: 1.0

Severity (Fatal, Serious, Minor): Minor

Type: (Coding Error, Design Issue, Suggestion, Documentation): Coding Error

Summary: Method should get rid of repeated specific characters, but it do not. 

Able to be reproduced? (Yes/No): Yes

What is the problem and how can it be reproduced?
The Javadoc for the method splitQuery, inside class DecodeHintManager, states that the method should ignore repeated specific characters, such as double ampersands, using only the first one. After unit tests, we find out that it although it ignores the repeated characters, the final result will be different as if you had only a single specific character.

Lollipop has an entirely new camera API: https://developer.android.com/reference/android/hardware/camera2/package-summary.html

It might be worth to support it, on API levels 21 and above.

API 21+ still contains the old camera API of course, and I don't think it makes sense to _require_ API 21+  just for this anytime in the next few years. At this point, there is no more dev on this project anyway. So I think this won't happen here, but could happen in another project based on this code.

@srowen After following the issues on this repo for a few weeks, might I offer the suggestion that the README be updated to clearly state at the top that this project is in maintenance mode? And the limitations on what pull requests will be accepted and what issues addressed?

https://github.com/zxing/zxing/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md ? this is the standard Github way to pop up a message when opening a PR. Straightforward bug fixes are fine but I don't want to get into new features or moderately complex changes.

@srowen Ah, I didn't see that. (Hence the reason for the suggestion in the README, where bold or large print is near impossible to miss when visiting a repo.) When opening an issue, GitHub merely presents a link to the guidelines, which I'm guessing most people don't click on. ;)

Just my passing thought. :) I'm actually really glad to see quality apps like this in a very stable position rather than changing frequently. It's been a reliable companion to every device I've had since 2009.

I tried a few versions before 4.7.3 and them don't work too.
I have P760 CM12.1 and this problem I have with any alternative room I tried.

When using http://zxing.org/w/decode.jspx with the following image, I noticed that the raw bytes are are wrong, even though the raw text is correct.

![datamatrix](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10532201/7406749/862abff2-ef08-11e4-9982-a80ef352abdb.jpg)

<S_CODE_TOKEN>
I suspect the raw bytes are in fact correct if the text is, right? These are the encoded codewords themselves. Maybe you are expecting a different codeword encoding than what the encoder chose?

II expect an ASCII character set where e.g. a capital 'D' is 0x44, not 0x45.

Strangely, the text is correct, but the bytes are not.

This makes the online service unusable for anyone interested in the binary data.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>
Why do you expect these codewords? There are many valid encodings for a string. That is, this barcode has the bytes it reports. This sounds like a question about controlling your encoder.

The image I gave as an example is a franking mark of the Deutsche Post. It uses a very simple ASCII encoding e.g. for the first three bytes: it's always Hex:444541 => ASCII: DEA.

See: http://www.deutschepost.de/content/dam/mlm.nf/dpag/images/p/premiumadress/premiumadress_neu/mlfvm_8_premiumadress_1_0_18_en.pdf

Maybe I've totally misunderstood the whole concept and you are right about those strange "encodings" for a "string" or "controlling your encoder". But then your concept is not usable, because people simply expect to see the byte values which match the encoded binary data.

But I still believe that there is just a nasty bug in the bytes printing loop.

Yeah what you see is the Data Matrix "encodation" of the string, which is not a simple ASCII or ISO-8859-1 representation. It has various modes to encode / compress strings. This starts in "ASCII encodation", which actually encodes most characters as ASCII + 1 values.

I see. Then my incident is no bug, but an improvement.

This service, for instance, prints the original binary data, as defined in the Deutsche Post specification: http://online-barcode-reader.inliteresearch.com/default.aspx

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

To simplify, there are three representations of the same data:
1. The Data Matrix encodation, using things like C40 and byte mode, as an array of bytes
2. The string, as an array of characters
3. That same string, encoded according to something like ISO-8859-1

It's not valid to put 3 into the barcode itself; that is not how strings are encoded in a Data Matrix barcode. 1 is how they are encoded. 1 is what the tool shows you. However it still represents the same string in 2. You can encode the string according to 3, yourself, but that is not the purpose of the tool. It's showing you the actual content of the barcode, which is not the bytes in 3, but bytes in 1.

When using the QR code reader with a front facing camera (non-default camera) if you turn the screen off and on (pressing power button) the camera being used changes to the default camera. This occurs because when the screen is turned off and on the surfaceView is not destroyed causing a different  behavior in CaptureActivity.onResume(). The surfaceView not being destroyed causes the CameraManager to open the camera before setting the cameraId. This pull request has reordered these operations to make sure the manual setting of cameraId inside CaptureActivity.onResume() occurs before the CameraManager opening the camera.

For more information see the following post:
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/zxing/CguxsAm0SjE
Yes that seems fine to just move the initialization later. Thanks!

New users probablly won't easily find the option to scan a inverted code.
That being said, it is still quite time consuming to switch the mode.
Maybe someone has the time to to implement automatic detection of inverted codes as enhancement.
As amateur I would assume it is pretty easy to spawn to tasks, one for normal and one for inverted, and wait for the first one to generate a hit? On modern phones with multi core cpu's it should also be just as fast as just scanning "normally"?

Yeah the problem is just 'detecting inverted codes' -- this is the same as scanning for a barcode. Yes you can spend more cores on it but you could also spend more cores on reading more frames. The nice thing about using the camera's inverse mode is it's free, in that the CPU is not inverting the image. 

The drawback is simply that it's not automatic. I think inverted codes are rare enough that it's not worth it.

I am not working on the project now, and at this stage am not sure I would want to accept a patch that implements this either for the reasons above. However, anyone can fork the app and implement it.

Performance is a good reason against it, yes.
If a patch were to deliver a setting to turn on a entirely optional mode with cpu image inverting and barcode detection, would it more likely be accepted?

Hm, so the code changes necessary to scan for both are probably not crazy but not trivial either. It would also change functionality that's been in there for a while that people are a little bit used to. It's not a bad idea but this is really in maintenance-only mode now and I'm more interested in keeping it as it is and fixing small bugs rather than evolving how it works. I fear change at this point.

Off topic but, I'd be pleased to see someone re-write and open source a fully modern version of the app. If re-written from scratch it could probably be a lot cleaner and simpler. The current code is pretty fine but has evolved from a starting point in Android 0.9.

I added the pull request https://github.com/zxing/zxing/pull/323 with my work on support for DMRE as described in http://www.aim-d.de/images/stories/pdfs/Arbeitskreise/Barcode/aim_spec_dmre_2014-09-22.pdf

It is functional enough for my needs, but I think it needs at least a good look from a maintainer before proper inclusion into zxing.
(Only closing this since it's pretty well encapsulated in the pull request itself)

This is a functional (but not clean) implementation of Data Matrix Rectangular Extensions as defined in the specification http://www.aim-d.de/images/stories/pdfs/Arbeitskreise/Barcode/aim_spec_dmre_2014-09-22.pdf

The implementation is divided in 3 separate commits:

https://github.com/zxing/zxing/commit/c815a4babb3708f1ae3e1115bb5dbb61d50cd4b8:
This adds the rectangles to the datamatrix definition tables.

https://github.com/zxing/zxing/commit/f2a32a45f053215175fa6750a006106b44a0705a:
This changes the threshold for determining a rectangular datamatrix form. This is necessary, because the old threshold excluded some of the new rectangles. It has the side effect of test failures in the datamatrix code, but AFAICS it has no effect on the functionality itself.

https://github.com/zxing/zxing/commit/e6713ae554c44fb158e49e7139a5441165db71af:
Some of the new forms resulted in an ArrayOutOfBoundsException. As I am not able to fix this cleanly I implemented this worlaround. The Exception may probably be fixed easily by a developer with more in-depth knowledge...

The extended rectangular data matrix symbols can be created by using a fork of the zint library 
http://sourceforge.net/u/oehhar/zint/ci/master/tree/

The extension seems to be adopted to ISO
http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_technical_committee.html?commid=45332

Great work ! DMRE is really important and will have lots of use cases.

For printing, one may use zint:
Binaries:
http://www.eurodatacouncil.org/de/doks-downloads.html
Source Code:
https://sourceforge.net/projects/zint/

Thank you, great work,
Harald

Yeah, it's a funny problem. That little region passes the heuristics for a finder pattern quite easily, so it keeps misreading. A little change can change it. Also try rotating the image a bit. It's a weakness of the heuristic that shows up in rare cases like this. I don't know of a good way to fix it without hurting performance for most codes though.

What that tends to mean is that the driver has a bug. The basic form is:
1. driver says it supports X, like some preview size
2. app sets X
3. driver fails, and all configuration is ignored

As you can see the change has nothing to do with brightness. 

However I am also not able to reproduce this on a Nexus 4, 5 or 6 on Android 4.x / 5.x. Try the various device bug workaround settings, and try different brightness settings, in the app's Settings.

Instead of using the request code as a parameter, preserves the previous api of `parseActivityResult()` and delegates its implementation to a new `parseActivityResult()` which adds a boolean parameter to determine whether to use the static (hardcoded) REQUEST_CODE, if such parameter is true, it behaves as before, if it false it doesn't check against the request code.

A better alternative would be to honor original `parseActivityResult`'s `requestCode` in the code, but it would require a change in the API.
This doesn't check any request code though. I thought you needed to be able to configure what code you look for? You need to check it at some level.

You specify the request code in the `startActivityForResult(..)` of the scan intent caller, once it returns via `onActivityResult(...)` you determine whether to match it or not. It is the responsibility of the caller to match the requestCode.

So if I want to use a custom request code I could do:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

And then:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

In this case the request codes are static, but they could be dynamic.
I hope this is self explanatory.

Thank you.

Yes, but I thought you wanted to expose control over the request code to the caller. Right now you can't; I thought this would entail another overloaded `initiateScan` method. I don't recognize the `createScanIntent()` method.

Why make the caller handle this logic? the point of the integration code is to handle it for you. At least it does at the moment. Yes it's getting a little overkill to pass in the request code and expected one just for it to check equality, but I think it's less convoluted than checking it and also passing in a new flag that disables a similar check.

You need the caller to handle the logic because there is only `onActivityResult()` handler per caller, you can't define a result listener for the Integrator. So one way or another, you'll need to map the requestCode (wrapped by the integrator or not) to the caller, to know which integrator made which request.

Regarding the `createScanIntent()` I just realized it's not there, I thought it was part of the official ZXing project, but it turns out to be part of https://github.com/journeyapps/zxing-android-embedded but not of its upstream (maybe it was added later). So basically I modified the IntentIntegrator API of a version I'm not consuming. :no_mouth: 

We can leave this PR on hold until I clarify this.
Yes, so the caller has to specify the request code at the outset. I think that can be tacked on to the API without trouble. Yes there is no `createScanIntent` here otherwise.

When I force Okapi to apply this bitmask I get the image below, which _does_ scan with ZXing, but which looks identical to the original. So the original image is a valid barcode and ZXing can decode it. I'm now thinking the problem is the quality of the image. Perhaps there isn't enough contrast?

![qr315_2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5260355/7901771/8b7f7640-0791-11e5-824a-6e5c2d0b3325.png)

The current implementation of `initiateScan()` uses a fixed request code when calling `startActivityForResult(...)`, which could be bypassed by calling `createIntent()` and starting the intent activity externally. 

But `parseActivityResult()` cannot be bypassed, because REQUEST_CODE is hardwired in the code.

It would be desirable to have a version of `initiateScan()` and `parseActivityResult()` that receives the request code as argument.
I think that's fine, do you want to make a PR that adds a getter/setter for a request code, which defaults to the current value?

I have developed a simple web app we use for tracking boxes at work which updates a database.

The boxes all have barcodes attached.

This is somewhat simplified, but for the purposes of this bug report I have two pages in the web app:
- Look up a box
- Add a new box

On the "add a new box" page I have a button which links to Barcode Scanner with a URL like:
http://zxing.appspot.com/scan?ret=https%3A%2F%2Fmyserver.example.com%2Faddbox.php%3F%26xid%3D%7BCODE%7D

On the "look up a box" page I have a similar button but it links to a different URL:
http://zxing.appspot.com/scan?ret=https%3A%2F%2Fmyserver.example.com%2Flookupbox.php%3F%26xid%3D%7BCODE%7D

However, I find if I go to "add a new box", scan a barcode with a particular value (doesn't seem to matter what type of barcode, I've reproduced with code 128 and with QR code), I am redirected correctly. But if I later go to "look up a box" and scan the same barcode, it returns me to addbox.php not lookupbox.php even though the link on the "look up a box" page was definitely correct.

If I scan a different barcode on the "look up a box" page I'm correctly redirected to lookupbox.php. If I clear all zxing's app data, and go to the "look up a box" page, and scan the same barcode, I'm also correctly redirected to lookupbox.php.

It looks like zxing is somehow caching the ret= value along with a particular barcode and refusing to change it on a later scan of the same code.

This breaks my web app's functionality. I guess the only way I can really work around it is by redirecting all scans to the same scan.php page and then using PHP session variables or something to tell scan.php where I really want to be redirected to. This is, quite obviously, a pain.

When trying to encode the string "_DTCP01" (without quotes), the DataMatrixWriter delivers a wrong BitMatrix. The BitMatrix represents the string "_DTCP04 47" (without quotes).

The issue is easy to reproduce with the given string. Other examples work.

This is actually a very annoying issue, since the reason for the behavior is not clear. Seems to be somehow related to the leading asterix.

Remark:
Barcode4j has the same issue. IText's BarcodeDatamatrix renders the barcode as expected.
As far as I understood the zxing package history, the DataMatrix implementation is based on Barcode4j - so maybe this is an inherited issue.

Hm, in this case, the given dimension is so small that only 5 codewords can be encoded. After encoding 6 of the 7 characters, all 5 are used up. The code doesn't write the unlatch, but a comment in the code says it's not required, which I could believe (i.e. the decoder assumes an unlatch when there can't be another triplet in the stream because there's only 1-2 codewords left). However it has still got 1 character to encode and it actually _encodes_ it in ASCII, but that 6th character is dropped. That itself seems like a little bug, but the right behavior is to fail the encoding, right? there isn't enough room in any encoding? That is to say I am not sure if it's an example of _this_ issue.

I think the followiing patch is the  solution:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Small explanation, if one character is left and there is exactly one codeword free than you
dont have to unlatch.
In all other case you have to unlatch because there is enough room left or adding a codeword will result in a bigger symbol info.

Hm, the previous patch only fixes that one case. If an additional character should be encoded which isn't supported by the X12 encoder than the result is garbage.
I added a german umlaut `*DTCP01ä`.
If an unlatch is necessary should be decided by the remaining characters in the context.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

I walked through the logic, and it seems OK. All but the last character are encoded as follows:

(X12 latch) : 238
`*DT` : 9 10
`CP0` : 104 141

There is no space left at this point within the currently smallest pattern that can fit, which holds 5 codewords. So it skips the unlatch and continues, and ends up encoding the final character in ASCII:

`1` : 50

It then picks a 12x12 pattern to fit 8 codewords, and fills the remaining 2 spots with padding. So, I don't see that this is encodable in 10x10?

I suppose the odd thing is that with 8 codewords, there is room for a latch, then. I don't know if it is supposed to go back and fix that, but I don't think it's the issue here?

In my opinion the logic isn't OK. The method handleEOD should not only rely on the length of the current buffer. It should be based upon the remaining characters in the context object to determine how many characters are left. As far as I understand the specification the unlatch codeword can only be missed if there is only one character left for encoding before the error correction codewords are added.
That's not the case here. There are two padding codewords before error correction.
It looks more terrible if you try to encode data which needs an encodation switch from X12 to another one. If I try `*DTCP01äaaaÜÖöüß?AbCaaa` it results in something like this after decoding `*DTCP041UEXLBSY>V*ISC9>D4B*YMJ0X5CRWGO320,`
If I modify the source like I mentioned above the result is ok.

Yes, all OK except that last part, although I think we're on to a different issue. In 12x12, it sounds like it can't omit the unlatch.

I think I understand the logic now. Here's what I have after tweaking the condition a little bit for IMHO a tiny bit of extra clarity:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

So in the last clause though, I understand why you don't unlatch with no data left to encode (I don't think this occurs though). But if you have 1 left to encode, don't you hit the same problem? If you expand the code capacity, don't unlatch, then encode the final char, you still have padding. Does this not still need the same check on `available`?

I never reached the last clause with getRemainingCharacters == 1. If one is left to encode it was caught by `if (count == 1)`. But you are right. If that one case occurs it should also do an unlatch.
Nevertheless, I look through the logic and I think it can be written in a shorter and in my opinion clearer way:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

The encode method needs a little modification which makes it also a bit cleaner (of course, in my opinion). The method `signalEncoderChange(newMode);` is now only called at one place.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Thinking about it the other way around, the only case where you do not unlatch is where there is 1 character left and 1 codeword available, right? I think that matches the logic in both versions of the method above. I like your simpler version; is `context.getRemainingCharacters() != 1 || available != 1` an even simpler condition to latch?

The `handleEOD` method is overridden from the parent and that's harder to change, so I am not sure if that's as easy as this change.

Anyway both conditions make my little test case pass, for the `*DTCP01` case. I have it expecting the unlatch, before finally encoding the 1 and padding with 1 codeword: `238 9 10 104 141 254 50 129`

In case of `handleEOD` and the call to `signalEncoderChange`: the call can also be made in the `encode` method after `handleEOD`.

That way the logic is more centralized. Are you up for making that change?

It would be better in this way, but I think that it could have some update issues. From what I can see in debug mode, the `HistoryManager` instance used for saving the records is not updated when I close the preferences activity, so it would keep the old pref value until a restart.
If you want I can save a `SharedPreferences` object at construction time in `HistoryManager`, and check the boolean value when the two methods (`addHistoryItem` and `addHistoryItemDetails`) are called. In this way it should be logically correct, and there should not be update issues.

We use this in ZXING in with our data collection applications for warehouse logistics.
Often we scan barcodes that conform to the GS1 standard, that contain multiple fields.
For variable length fields, a FNC1 character (ascii 29) is used as a terminator.
For 1D Code128 formated barcodes, the FNC1 character is suppressed.
What change are you suggesting? Can you make a pull request?

I am suggesting that all the data be passed when a code 128 barcode is scanned, including the non-printable characters such as Ascii 29. The behaviour is more correct when scanning a 2D Data Matrix barcode that is has multiple fields that conform to the GS1 standard.

Nonprintable characters are still part of the returned string. They are just not visible. I know that it is unspecified, however, what to do with FNC1 in some formats where the reader is not interpreting them as commands. I think DM suggests mapping to ASCII 29 and I did the same in other formats that do not specify. Is the suggestion to make Code 128 behave this way? There is an `ASSUME_GS1` hint for this that is probably what you need. Reopen if not.

ISO standards demand the following behavior:
FNC1 at the first position - This is tranlated to the symbology identifier according ISO/IEC 15424. A Code 128 for example get ]C0 as identifier if there was no FNC1 at the first position. If there was one then the symbology identifier gets ]C1. There is no other translation of FNC1 if it is at the first position. In case the FNC1 is beeing use at another position (except second) as field separator then the ISO standards demand that the FNC1 character shall be translated to the GS character ASCII 29.

The Code 128 (ISO/IEC 15417) modifiers 
0 a normal Code 128 - no FNC characters at the first or second position
1 is a FNC1 at the first position. GS1 call then this Code 128 "GS1 128"
2 is a FNC1 charater at the secon position
4 is a concantenated symbol according to ISBT demands
Eh, yes I think that's what is happening here? what is the difference between what happens and what you expect?

If its working like that then ignore the posting. Typically this
behaviour is working incorrect for most smartphone scanning apps. ;-)
Am 08.03.2015 um 14:43 schrieb Sean Owen:

> Eh, yes I think that's what is happening here? what is the difference
> between what happens and what you expect?

@jiggo Do you have tried my approach from second comment above?

The problem is that there is no constructor for `IntentIntegrator` that takes `android.support.v4.preference.PreferenceFragment`. Could you implement such a constructor?

The code in the second comment should work, but I'd rather not use that ugly hack.

It's strange that the requestCode is produced by the library. 

Normally it should be the client code that should supply a request code, so that it can switch on it once the scanner library calls back `OnActivityResult`.

Instead, the approach chosen obliges to inspect the request via `IntentIntegrator.parseActivityResult()`, which poses at least two issues:

1/ this is needless processing which can be avoided by switching on a client produce request code
2/ there is a potential for request code conflicts - now, an app must make sure to never user a request code that might be in use by the ZXing library.

solution: the client side must supply a request code in the `IntentIntegrator()` constructor.

a workaround seems to be to switch on `IntentIntegrator.REQUEST_CODE`, but this is not really documented and could be added to https://github.com/zxing/zxing/wiki/Scanning-Via-Intent#intentintegrator

Yes there's a potential for conflict, though remote. The cost of the switch is trivial. I don't agree it's better to force the client to provide a code, but, it's also no big deal to add an overload that accepts a request code when the request is made and when it's handled.

IMHO your arguments are weak.

I'm sorry I have to get personal here, but it is my impression that the Android aspect is badly represented in this project.  It now feels that the code was written by someone who knows enough about Java but not enough about Android: e.g. imposing the request code, suggesting a non-standard way to handle the return code, not dealing with the Support Library, not accepting significant merge requests, and the very actual fact that yet another Android dev (me) is hitting this issue.

What is needed is someone with good Android experience to manage the Android part of ZXing, but I understand that someone needs to take the challenge (so please don't take this as negative critic).

I created a small project that demonstrates that the integrator component does not work as advertised, and needs to be rewritten: https://github.com/axd1967/test_qr_zxing .

... and just after writing this, I hit this OMG (which solves my problem): 

https://github.com/axd1967/test_qr_zxing/commit/ec44b051388c230c510d5f31a412a927135386fc

I think this is yet another argument that request code handling is wrong, because there is no reason to retransmit the request code back to `IntentIntegrator.parseActivityResult()`. The request code is an implementation detail of the client code.

see also https://github.com/zxing/zxing/blob/c219e28d5695fddb62abf8ce8184a0e53a314ad2/android-integration/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/integration/android/IntentIntegrator.java#L416

so, to recap: thanks for the library, but the Android part needs some overhaul.

by the way: in my projects I tend to avoid the wiki.

why? because the content depends on code evolutions, so the content should be some Markdown (or other format) page inside the repository, that is adapted whenever code changes.

(the IMO only advantage of the wiki is the simplified diff tool... it should be implemented everywhere, not only on wiki pages.)

Hi there!
I've discovered, that zxing (a least, android barcode scanner) decodes DataMatrix codes with unicode text as ASCII (and, so brake it). I.e. it displays `ÑÐµÑÑ` instead of `тест` (ciryllic "test").

OTOH, QR-encoded unicode is decoded fine.

Can somebody fix that (or, at least, advice/guide me how to fix it)?

90% of the time people report this it is because the barcode is incorrect. Is it UTF 8 encoded or has an ECI segment? Are you sure it is not your console? Until there is info like a barcode I couldn't say.

ok, some additional info:
1) it is UTF-8 barcode (generated by libdmtx. And it decodes fine as unicode by libdmtx too). Although it, exactly, maybe something with libdmtx encryption algo (I'd be glad to test generation with zxing itself to be sure, but neither test app nor scanner can **generate** DMTX) ;)
2) I'm sure it is not my console.
3) There is "тест" message: 
![dmtx_test](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/268102/5746911/707d936a-9c55-11e4-80f6-85b7cab1a4dd.png)

4) can you describe, how to check for ECI segment, please? Then I'd be able to answer this question too....
is it any more info that I can provide?

The barcode encodes 6 bytes with Base 256 encoding, and that is the entire content of the barcode. Without an ECI segment, the spec says that the bytes are interpreted as ISO-8859-1, so the result from the library is correct. The barcode needs an ECI segment.

Now, I also don't know that ECI support was ever finished for Data Matrix. But that wouldn't be hard to tack on since it's implemented for QR code. But this barcode does not have one.

btw, I've another dmtx-barcode with same encoded text. And, as far as I understand, it has mark of extended ascii (and generated by another app). And, to be honest, I have absolutelly no idea, how should look like **proper** ECI mark "there is UTF-8 inside" (I bet, it is not enough to just have \x241 as first byte in codewords. Advice me, please, how does it marked for QRs?

![dmtx_klipper](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/268102/5748646/72a0f41c-9c63-11e4-9f61-bd331d4df01c.png)

Yeah do you have the spec? codeword 241 introduces an ECI segment. The encoding should be the same as in QR codes. These aren't described in the spec but you can see how it is implemented in QR codes. It should just be followed by a single 8-bit value for the character set. UTF8 is 26.

The zxing decoder does **not** support ECI with Data Matrix, as evident by the code:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

at zxing/core/src/main/java/com/google/zxing/datamatrix/decoder/DecodedBitStreamParser.java

It looks like @msva was correct in reporting this issue. As zxing does support ECI and auto UTF-8 detection for QR, it should be simple to add these capabilities to the Data Matrix decoder. @srowen,  please re-open this issue.

I forked the old deleted C++ code into it's own [light-weight repo](https://github.com/glassechidna/zxing-cpp), as I wanted to build some [regular Ruby (not JRuby) bindings](https://github.com/glassechidna/zxing_cpp.rb).

The Ruby bindings are actually just a fork of [Steven's Ruby bindings](https://github.com/smparkes/zxing.rb), where I've mostly just removed all the JRuby and MacRuby bits and then added all the stuff necessary to package and publish a [zxing_cpp gem](http://rubygems.org/gems/zxing_cpp).

Anyway, this commit just adds some info about the projects to the README so people looking for an active C++ port and some Ruby bindings can find them.

create minSize Dimension from provided width and height. If minsize is provided inside hints, it still gets overwritten
it was not tested, tests failed at aztec barcode

Hm, yeah, these params aren't used at all are they? There is this `EncodeHintType.MIN_SIZE` that does the same thing, but it's only used in DataMatrix. I think this is a weirdness held over from the fact that this code was imported from another code base. I think I might also deprecate those hints.

I'm seeing the same problem as reported in https://github.com/zxing/zxing/issues/361 and I think it's due to this change. Here the min / max size are really setting the min / max _symbol_ dimension, not the rendered image size. This causes it to fail for example if you ask for a 300x300 image as there is no DM symbol that large.

This reveals another lesser problem, which is probably the original issue here, that the DM encoder doesn't try to then render an image of the given dimensions. You get a tiny image whose dimensions match the symbol's. That's better than not working but still not exactly consistent.

ok, after so much time passed i dont dig deeply again to this, but the behaviour of providing the preferred dimensions should be unified across different Writer implementations. Feel free to close this if its not.

When using com.google.zxing.datamatrix.DataMatrixWriter encode(String contents, BarcodeFormat format, int width, int height, Map<EncodeHintType,?> hints) and providing width and height, none of these parameters are pushed to the size of resulting BitMatrix, so it is really small even if dimensions are 400x400 for example.
Can you give an example? I think it is scaled so that modules have an integer number of pixels. Consider the padding at the edges too.

It fails in decoding text encodation, with the triplet of values {1, 33, 4}. I re-read the spec and it looks like this isn't valid: 1 means "shift 2", and shift 2 has no value for 33. That's why it stops decoding.

On rereading 5.2.5.3 in the spec, which covers values outside the ASCII basic set, it suggests a special encoding that encodes instead the character corresponding to (ASCII value - 128). ü is 252, and 252-128 = 124. The pipe character | is 124, and the text encodation of | is value 33. A-ha.

So I reviewed the spec, and I am confused more. I don't think {1, 33, 4} is valid. 1 means "shift 2". According to the spec, it should be followed by 30 (upper shift), then 1 (shift 2 again), then 33 as the encoding for ü. So I'm not sure this DM code is quite correct. There is no upper shift in sight here and that's what lets you select upper-ASCII chars in all cases in DM.

That said, the code doesn't handle 4-value groups like {1, 30, 1, 33}. In fact I'm not sure the spec make sense here, as everything else is triplets of values. It does correctly handle lots of upper-ASCII character cases; this one has me confused though since the DM code here doesn't seem to match the spec, but the spec doesn't quite make sense.
Hmm, that's weird, because I can run the decoding process just fine on http://online-barcode-reader.inliteresearch.com/ :(

I think you are right. Even on inlite the umlauts are corrupted. The DM above is part of an editable pdf. It's generated when changing the content of the pdf. I think the umlauts are generated wrong somehow.

Now I understand that all the data is encoded with triplets, and the spec isn't saying otherwise. It just means that four values are needed to encode ü. 

Hm, so the sequence starting where the ü is encoded is 1, 33, 4, 28, 27, 16, ... 27 and 16 are clearly 'n'and 'c'. So 1, 33, 4, 28 is supposed to encode ü. The spec seems pretty clear that it should be 1, 30, 2, 28. Because the 1 and 28 match up, it seem clear this is definitely trying to encode ü. But I can't see how 1, 33, 4, 28 is correct. 33 is not valid in shift 2.

The online decoder might just be skipping 33, in which case I think you will get "M0onch.." or similar.

I'm happy to reopen this if someone can point out how 1, 33, 4, 28 encodes ü. In the meantime I identified some small cleanups for this code.

One more question. I need a little help how to tell the developer who creates the PDF what needs to be fixed in his datamatrix generator. Therefor I need to know what kind of encoding is used in general for datamatrix and how he can encode those umlauts right. 

Thank you very much in advance.
Mike

I'm no expert, and there's still a little chance I am missing something about the spec. But it's in text encodation mode at this stage, which is perfectly fine and able to store ü. You can see my description above about what I see and what I expect. The relevant spec is 5.2.5.3 in ISO 16022.

But what I noticed was that if the name name is long, then the qrcode strinks in size. I need the qrcode to be of 300 x 300 size. 

I am generating these qrcode using MRI ruby 2.1.1 with zxing/core jar in a Rails(v 4.1.0) web app.
ATM i am using an older version(not sure which version) but I have tried with version 3.1.0 and I am getting the same result.

Below are some sample I have generated with my code and older version of core jar. Notice the 3rd qrcode is smaller even though all images are of  same size.
Does anyone know a fix to this issue. Please help me out here.

![q1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4658665/5164891/1c860988-7403-11e4-8782-5986de694444.png)
![q2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4658665/5164892/1ea39244-7403-11e4-9cfc-86bb3d0b4602.png)
![q3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4658665/5164893/220b570a-7403-11e4-8c12-38b185e20056.png)
![q4](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4658665/5164895/24bc45f4-7403-11e4-8ff0-a9ae9a5f1f18.png)

It's pretty straightforward. The 3rd value requires more codewords to encode. The encoder must step up a version or two, meaning bigger QR codes. Since you constrained the output size, and because the module size must be an integer number of pixels, it has to make modules smaller.

There's no 'fix' since this is correct behavior, but if you want all the QR codes to be the same version (module dimension) then you can constrain the size of the input you feed to the encoder.

Thanks a million for the quick reply.
When you say 'constrain the size of the input' do you mean the input characters or something else.
Also if its not asking too much can you give me a sample configuration to make all the qrcode images of same size (same version) even when the input size is large (since it will large most of the times) and also if there is any workaround or monkey patch to get them to same size.

Yes, size of the string you are encoding. As I say there's no 'workaround' since it is working correctly. You're literally asking for a bunch of data to fit in exactly the same space, which isn't generally possible.

When I scan a Code 128 barcode and rotate the scanner a bit the value returned is different than the actual barcode value.

About 1% to 2% of the scans returned invalid value.
I scan a Code 128 barcode with a value of 4001599 and the following returned on a good scan:

result.text=4001599 
result-format=CODE_128 
result.cancelled=false

Then when the scan is not 100% in the window or a bit at an angle I get the following result on the same barcode.

result.text=18112146 
result.format=UPC_E 
result.cancelled=false 

My conclusion is that the UPC_E does not calculate a check digit.
Sometimes the scan only capture a part of the barcode and interpret it as a UPC-E barcode.

Is there any possibility for this to get fixed?

Eventually you will find a UPC-E in noise or a carpet. It is a short format without checksum, yes. You should disable it if you know you're not scanning for it. Here I think the Code 128 is not readable because it is incomplete so after a while you see a phantom code.

Are there any existing thoughts about separating out classes like BitMatrix or the generic Reed Solomon stuff  and alike into generic, separate projects? org.apache.commons might be a good destination, more precisely http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-math/

I'm not against it; at the same time I don't know if it's as widely applicable as that. It would be good to have a generic Reed Solomon implementation although I bet this one would have to be refactored to really support general RS. It's a little bit tailored to the variant in QR codes. People can already depend on the core library here to get at this code and it's a smallish dependency-free artifact. On the flip side I'd kinda not like to bring in all of Commons Math or similar just to get back these classes.

That said I'm not against refactorings of the code in-place to make it more usable, or against porting it upstream to another more common library if someone wants to take that on.

See the single commit notes.
I do not retain any copyrights to the stuff contained in this pull request, do with it what you want to.

Ah, interesting. There is some history here. So as you can see, a lot of flow control is handled by exceptions. Some people say this is madness; for this type of code, where control returns from deeply nested routines frequently (in case of a decode error), I think it ends up being simpler. The problem is that exceptions are expensive to instantiate. However, as you can see, this uses 'singleton' exceptions. It is actually faster than flow control not based on exceptions, by a tiny bit. That mattered a lot in early days of Android, and still does a bit.

That said, it's really `NotFoundException` that is thrown frequently. The others are rare. I see you're arguing for instantiating `FormatException` every time, so that the location of the exception is clear. You could do something similar for `ChecksumException` but not `NotFoundException`.

However, if the purpose is really for testing only, I'd suggest something even simpler. Add a system property that causes a freshly-instantiated exception to be thrown instead of the singleton, and turn it on for tests. What say?

I will make a few more comments shortly

Oh BTW, you do retain copyright in your contribution. You just agree to license it under the Apache License 2.0 by offering it for inclusion here.

Also the commits would ideally be squashed in this pull request before merging.

The rest -- bits of it look positive. I don't get the changing of the seeding of the RNG; why is the alternative better? Is there a way to break down these changes into smaller logical units or explain their purpose more individually?

There were two test cases marked as "flaky". That was because the random number sequences were not the same at each test execution, so the errors popped up only randomly. Instantiating SecureRandom with a seed is not necessarily the same regarding repeatability of the sequence as instantiating Random using a seed: the first one uses an arbitrary random number generator depending on the JDK config or so.

I'll undo the Exception stuff.

Hm, so seeding `SecureRandom` doesn't make its sequence repeatable? I tried it and that seems right. That's no good. Yes, just use `Random` I suppose.

I kind of like the system property thing for exceptions. Feel free to give it a go or I can do it.

If possible let's break this down a bit into discrete changes and I can rapidly commit them.
Looking strong; my only last request is to squash and force-push the commits.
Done.
The Travis build took like 45 minutes, but I think it could be a Travis problem. I'm looking at it locally first to make sure this doesn't drastically slow down the tests.

Just noticed that QR has support for splitting a text (and hopefully binary file as well) into multiple QR codes that can be scanned sequentially to reconstruct the file.

This might be useful. How hard would it be to support this?

---

src: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12905485/storing-a-bmp-image-in-a-qr-code

> The best source of information you can use is the norm about QR Codes (ISO 18004:2006); it's possible (but not necessarily easy) to find it for free on the web.
> 
> The relevant part (section 9) of this norm says:
> 
> > "Up to 16 QR Code symbols may be appended in a structured format. If a symbol is part of a Structured Append message, it is indicated by a header block in the first three symbol character positions. The Structured Append Mode Indicator 0011 is placed in the four most significant bit positions in the first symbol character. This is immediately followed by two Structured Append codewords, spread over the four least significant bits of the first symbol character, the second symbol character and the four most significant bits of the third symbol character. The first codeword is the symbol sequence indicator. The second codeword is the parity data and is identical in all symbols in the message, enabling it to be verified that all symbols read form part of the same Structured Append message. This header is immediately followed by the data codewords for the symbol commencing with the first Mode Indicator."

---

http://www.onbarcode.com/qr_code/structured_append/

> Structured AppendBasic principles 
> 
> Structured append cannot be used in Micro QR Code. 
> 
> One QR Code 2005 symbol can be divided into up to 16 symbols. On the contrary, it can be appended into a structured format. If a symbol is a part of the structured append message, it can be represented by a header block in the first two and a half character positions The four most significant bit positions of the first symbol character set the Structured Append mode indicator 0011. 
> 
> In Structured Append mode, two Structured Append codewords follows indicators, which are placed in the four least significant bits position of the first symbol character, the eight bit position of the second symbol character and the four most significant bit position of the third symbol character respectively. The first codeword is symbol sequence indicator, the second one is parity data, which is identical in all append message to enable all readable symbols are part of the same Structured Append message. This header is followed by the data symbols commencing with the indicator of the first mode. If adopted other ECI mode rather than ECI default mode, each header block consisting of ECI indicator and ECI designator should follow Structured Append header.

Again, if you want to supply a patch, I'd look at it. I am not doing any more development work myself. This is a bit tricky to support since it means putting together many scans and the app has no good way to manage that. I think it would be a big change and so am skeptical that there is an easy/clean change that meaningfully supports this fairly niche use case. But it would not be so hard to return additional metadata about the structured append even if it's not acted on. I'll leave this open for a short while.

Yes 'Beeple' (Edit: he deleted his message) . Basically it allows for embedding small sequences of a larger file into multiple smaller barcodes.

This is useful in the case of sending public keys like this example:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

The issue with the usual method of cramming it in a single barcode is that the resulting barcode is too dense. So by keeping it as a smaller sequence of QR codes, you can more easily print it. (Btw it doesn't have to be public keys, it could be a html page, or a private key, or a small vector image of a map)

Edit: actually on reading the spec, this is how you read it: Here is a small excerpt:
Edit2: correction. After the first "MODE" nibble, it is followed _immediately_ by the sequence, total and parity. So thats about 2.5 bytes in total. Thanks chrisbainbridge

> The Structured Append mode indicator 0011 is placed in the four most significant bit positions in the first symbol character.This is immediately followed by two Structured Append codewords, spread over the four least significant bits of the first symbol character, the second symbol character and the four most significant bits of the third symbol character. The first codeword is the symbol sequence indicator (see 7.2). The second codeword is the parity data (see 7.3) and is identical in all symbols in the message, enabling it to be verified that all symbols read form part of the same Structured Append message. This header is immediately followed by the data codewords for the symbol commencing with the first mode indicator. If one or more ECIs other than the default ECI is in force, an ECI header for each ECI, consisting of the ECI mode indicator and ECI Designator, shall follow the Structured Append header

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

So say we have two QR structured append:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

In binary that means 

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

---

How to deal with the parity field? The specs also highlights this. You essentially just "XORing byte by byte the byte values of all the original input data before division into symbol
blocks. Mode Indicators, Character Count Identifiers, padding bits, Terminator and Pad Characters shall be excluded from the calculation.". For Kanji you XOR by 2-bytes, and for anything else, by 8bit shift. Here is a python example code to illustrate the point

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

---

To make it clear to you, here is a modified version of what "kenji_uno" saw in https://zxingnet.codeplex.com/discussions/364835. Stripped away all the fluff, so you can see how it looks within the program. Just remember that STRUCTURED_APPEND_SEQUENCE & STRUCTURED_APPEND_PARITY are actually in binary (First is split in 2 4bit nibbles, and second is an 8bit xored parity byte.). 

<S_CODE_TOKEN>
There is code to do this at http://programresource.net/en/2013/05/04/2202.html

I generated a QR Code for a Unicode text using a firefox Addon, Qr Code Image Generator 2.0.1 and when I tried to scan it from the app(version 4.7.0) on my phone but it doesnt get scanned at all. Does QR Code not work for Unicode or does this app not support the same.

This has been covered several times. Unicode is not an encoding; maybe you mean UTF-8. QR codes must contain ISO-8859-1 encoded text by nature. If you use a different encoding, you must encode an ECI segment specifying it. It will try to guess UTF-8 otherwise, but really, an ECI segment is required by your encoder.

These characters are not encodable in the ISO-8859-1 character set: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO/IEC_8859-1  This is the default for QR codes. To use other characters, encode the text as UTF-8. Technically you must also put in an ECI segment selecting UTF-8. But this app will usually guess UTF-8 correctly.

ok, I had a quick look at this. The PDF417 decoder first checks each line in the barcode image for potential codewords. Your image has several image lines encoding the same codeword (roughly between 3 and 7, depending on the location in the image). This can result in several different detected values for the same codeword. The decoder uses a majority voting system to determine the most likely candidate for each codeword. If there are several candidates which are equally likely, it will try to pass several detection results to the error correction algorithm, using the different values. This increases the detection rate of very hard to decode barcodes, but it also increases the chance of false positives, especially in barcodes with only very few error correction information. Your barcode has an error correction level of 1, which is very low. It is recommended to use at least level 2 for barcodes created and scanned in good quality. Higher levels should be used in environments that can't guarantee good printing and/or scanning quality.
I could add some logic to prevent trying too many different codeword value combinations for lower error correction levels, but this is not an exact science. I'd need a bigger test set to determine when to do what.
Thank you very much for your analysis. Currently I can't provide you with a bigger test set. It's probably more feasible to reprint the labels with a higher error correction level.

Micro QR was adopted as JIS X 0510 and it was released in November 2011.

Micro QR was standardized earlier in the main ISO spec, but, it's an optional element, and I have never seen it used. At this stage wouldn't consider a patch for it since the project is in maintenance mode only.

Hi,
I understand QRCodeMultiReader().decodeMultiple scans the entire image trying to find QRCode and it usually fails when there are multiple QRCodes close to each other.  However, whenever it does detect a QRCode, it will report the absolute image coordinate in the ResultPoints.

ByQuadrantReader does a much better job of detecting multiple QRCodes in an image, but ResultPoints appears to be relative to the quadrant instead of to the image.  Is there a way for ByQuadrantReader to provide the absolute image coordinate in ResultPoints?

For example:
QRCodeMultiReader().decodeMultiple would give:
"MyQRCodeText"
(746.5,634.5)
(744.5,549)
(835.0,545.5)

ByQuadrantReader  would give:
"MyQRCodeText"
(746.5,274.5)
(744.5,189.5)
(835.0,185.16667)
That is the intent. It could just be a bug. Can you have a look and maybe take a crack at a patch?
Sure thing.

I think I have handled this in other similar cases by translating the
ResultPoints at this level too, rather than down in the delegated code. If
the decode succeeds, you change the ResultPoint[] array to reflect that
they were relative to the cropped image.

Yes, what this means is that the camera driver has become corrupted. It returns 'null' on open, which it is not allowed to do in the API. It means a device bug.

Scanned QR code data: `WIFI:T:WPA;S:test;P:my_password\\;;`
-> Password in wpa_supplicant.conf: `my_password\;`

Scanned QR code data: `WIFI:T:WPA;S:test;P:my_password\\;`
-> Entry is not entered at all

Expected result is that the stored password is: `my_password\`

Backslash is the escape character in this 'format', which mimics MECARD. For this reason it must also end in `;;`. 

In your second example, the problem is just that it doesn't end in `;;` so is not considered valid. But in the first case, the password should indeed be just `my_password\`. I'll look into why that's wrong and add a test case.

The negative QR-Code is specified in ISO/IEC 18004. This should work as well as a negative data matrix (ISO/IEC 16022). Bar Codes are specified to use dark bars and light spaces only. In standardization negative bar codes don't exist.

White-on-black barcodes are an optional part of the QR code and DM specs. I don't think they are 'standard' for 1D symbologies. Hence there is a separate mode you enable to scan for them. However for reasons I don't understand the negative camera mode doesn't enable on some Android devices. This is really about support for camera color mode `negative`, not a question of the spec.

Negative is for Data Matrix and QR-Code in the normative part of the
standard. That means mandatory.
Negative is not specified for any bar code. That means optional.

Read section 5.2 of ISO 18004, where it marks reflectance reversal as optional for QR codes. Section 4.2 of ISO 16022 also marks this as an "additional" feature, but then actually marks reflectance reversal alone as non-optional with every other additional feature as optional. I think that means DM should read white on black too.

In any event I'm afraid I am not going to change this about the app at this stage, but would accept a fix to at least get the invert-image setting working on devices where it's not.

Chapter 5.2 of ISO/IEC 18004 is this
Reflectance reversal
Symbols are intended to be read when marked so that the image is either
dark on light or light on dark
(see Figures 1 and 2). The specifications in this International Standard
are based on dark images on a
light background, therefore in the case of symbols produced with
reflectance reversal references to dark
or light modules should be taken as references to light or dark modules
respectively.

Maybe its helps somebody who is still working at Zxing.

When checking out the source code under windows the line endings of the txt files in the test cases got converted to CRLF.
The .gitattributes files defines to leave the *.txt files with LF line ending. This way the tests also pass under Windows.
Oh nice one, does that fix the test problem for you?

Yes, it fixed the issues with the test cases 16 to 19 in the qrcode-5 backbox tests. These were the only ones that failed. 
The .gitattributes file defines the line ending on a per-repository basis and overrides an individual's core.autocrlf setting.
https://help.github.com/articles/dealing-with-line-endings

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

That's weird. I can think of two possible reasons off the top of my head. One is pretty unlikely: that the images get read slightly differently because underneath Java is delegating to different native libraries for image parsing. This happened a long time ago with JPEGs on Java 5 vs 6, but thought we fixed that by switching to PNGs. I think it might explain a few failures but not that many.

I also wonder if your checkout of the files containing the correct barcode contents changed things like line separators. That might cause it to mismatch the expected contents Again still seems a bit unlikely.

It all passes on Java 6, 7, and 9 on Travis CI (Linux of course). 

I'm not really sure but whatever it is is likely Windows specific. If you have any ideas that would make it work everywhere let me know. Otherwise not sure what to do.

I've just ignored the `QRCodeBlackBox5TestCase` with `@Ignore` and the build passed. So it looks like the problem is isolated to the `QRCodeBlackBox5TestCase`.
Executing the build in another vmware instance running Ubuntu 14.01 also succeeded.

Since they are all failing due to 'misreads', I suspect maybe my second theory is right. Do you see which test images actually fail in earlier logs? Does it look like the expected vs actual are actually the same? Then it could be line separators. I think there's a git setting that might auto-convert this.

I haven't seen your source code, but I guess there're some issues on reading Chinese.
According to GB/T 18284—2000 specification, in Chinese Hanzi (GB) mode 1101,we should put sub-charset indicator 0001 which represent GB2312. I am sure your source code has put it because ZXing android can read my barcode. But if I mixed some Japanese which including in GB2312 table,ZXing failed to read those Japanese characters but can read Chinese. I guess your decoder has a wrong GB2312 First byte range.

According to GB/T 18284—2000, the GB2312 Range is:
First Byte : &HA1-&HF7 and second byte:&HA1-&HFE

This exactly match GB2312 table （http://ash.jp/code/cn/gb2312tbl.htm）

'---------------------------------------------------------------------
The string to encode is : インドネシア,韩国有句俗语：三个铜板买房屋，千两黄金买邻居。インドネシア

ZXing Android application Read:韩国有句俗语：三个铜板买房屋，千两黄金买邻居。

you cab see ZXing decoder ignore front and backwrad Japanese which incuded in GB2312 table.
I am not clear how this relates to QR code character encoding, which uses ECI segments. This does not sound like the standard. Maybe you can suggest a patch to clarify.

No, my testing QR Code Image used Mode 1101,don't have ECI header.
I just download your code, I will test decodeHanziSegment.

Oh, this is "Hanzi" mode? Yes, that's not a part of the QR code spec itself but an unofficial extension.I don't quite understand what you are reporting, but the app itself does not decode GB2312, Java does. If you have a specific patch to suggest to the app, reopen this with an explanation of why it's needed.

Since December 2012, the QR code payments are standardized in the Czech Republic via the SPAYD format. The format is used with all local banks, all local invoicing software and almost all large invoice issuers, and it is applicable across the whole Europe. It would be nice to integrate the SPAYD support in the default ZXing scanner.

For more info about SPAYD, see:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Short_Payment_Descriptor
https://github.com/spayd/spayd-java
https://github.com/inmite/spayd-sdk
It sounds fairly niche. I think the few callers who need this should support it themselves. You can suggest a patch. At least it would be available for those that want it.

I will have a look and suggest the patch.

The local adoption of SPAYD was quite big (for example, Raiffeisenbank does 30% of all their online e-commerce payments via these QR codes) but we are dealing with the "chicken-egg problem" for a wider adoption across the EU.

So, _parsing_ this format is fairly simple. I don't think it's worth putting into the project, but it could be worth posting your addition for others to use. That can be done in your fork for example.

Acting on the payment info does not seem feasible though, not for the core app. You would definitely want a separate app for whatever this is. That would not be committed.

"com.google.zxing.client.android.SCAN"

intent.getStringExtra(ZXING_SCAN_RESULT_FORMAT) -> codabar
intent.getStringExtra(ZXING_SCAN_RESULT) -> 12345678904

does not contain the sentinels, (in this case: 12345678904 is the number)

and when it is passed to com.google.zxing.oned.CodaBarWriter

it is being validated and expected to have the sentinels (lines 39-47 fo CodaBarWriter's encode method).

![cropped barcode](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8050638/3460502/df20e0c0-0217-11e4-9bb5-57ad25831b99.png)

Here's the barcode I am scanning. You may have to enlarge it a bit to make it clear enough to scan.
Sentinel / guard patterns don't encode data, right? They are not returned since they do not map to content in the barcode.
Shouldn't the CodaBarWriter's encode add the sentinels, then, if they are missing?

Yeah it's a good point. Codabar is kind of weird since it lets you use different start/end characters, but as I understand they are not considered part of the content. But different values are used to distinguish different "applications". They are kind of metadata.

I forgot this until I looked at the code again: You can specify the hint `DecodeHintType.RETURN_CODABAR_START_END` to have them returned as part of the content. It's not the default, but is available for callers that want this info.

Hm. Maybe they should be returned as metadata, too.

I think it would be reasonable to do something symmetric on the other end, like, just add a default start/end character if not present, like A and E. 

Would that be helpful, and/or are you interested in trying a patch?
We added a default start/end character for now and will address this later.
I pushed a similar change -- try it out if you have a sec. It will add "A" as the start/end guard as a default. If either guard is specified, both must be, and must be valid.

ARGB Color model must be used to allow offColor be transparent
It's probably fine either way, but what does this accomplish? the output does not use the alpha channel and the current format says so.

As you can see in javadoc comment to BufferedImage.setRGB method: "The pixel is assumed to be in the default RGB color, TYPE_INT_ARGB, and default sRGB color space.". So using TYPE_INT_RGB here is just wrong - transparency bytes will not work.

Yes, transparency is not needed. That byte does not matter. `TYPE_INT_RGB` defines the `ColorModel` of the `BufferedImage`. The input to `BufferedImage.setRGB` is always interpreted as ARGB, yes, and then converted as best it can into the given `ColorModel`. I had figured `TYPE_INT_RGB` was more efficient since it doesn't bother storing an unused alpha channel. Right? are you actually observing a problem?

I really like the your zxing app and wanted to suggest this. Happy to program the Android/Javascript part of it if people are interested.

A HTTP service mode for zxing.
For better integration with websites.

Process:
1. User visits webapp/webpage.
2. App checks for xzing http sever.
3. Is the server running? If not, prompt to install, or open using intent URL that triggers the service to start.
4. zxing http server now running.
5. User clicks on "scan barcode" button.
6. Http requests are made every second to the zxing server url (ie http://localhost:8080).
7. The server returns two things:
    a. base64 encoded image of what the camera is seeing at that point
    b. the captured barcode data (returned once for every barcode recognition).
8. The javascript app show a small dialog to display the base64 image data and has a button to stop the barcode recognition.
9. A callback is issued every time a barcode is received.

This would produce seamless integration for web-apps :-D

Please let me know what you think.

Hi Sean,

When using an web app it's not ideal to go back and forth between the 
app and the webpage, especially when scanning multiple barcodes.
This basically provides access to the camera preview plus any decoded 
barcode text all from the web browser.

Plus it wraps all the web functionality in a jquery widget, you can 
invoke the widget and issue js callbacks to fire when a barcode is 
found. I think you would be the first app to provide such a feature :-)

Zxing is still doing all the handling of decoding and such.

Give it a go and let me know what you think.

Kind regards,
Michael

When scanning a barcode containing a link that doesn't have http(s) as scheme, only the host:port/path portion is recognized as link and clickable, e.g.:

QR code contains: opc.tcp://test.samplehost.com:4841
Clickable link: test.samplehost.com:4841

We're developing an Android application that has the opc.tcp scheme registered and would open if a link was clicked with the opc.tcp scheme. Using Barcode Scanner this is not possible, as it opens test.samplehost.com:4841 in the browser. Please improve the URL parser to detect non-http(s) schemes and allow to click them.

Cheers!

Yes, I think the issue is that things like `opc.tcp` was not recognized as a valid scheme, but on looking at the RFC, it is. I just changed the logic to match the RFC. Now this is actually recognized as a URI not text. That should give you a button to open the full URI. Android looks like it only linkifies the host/path for some reason, but the "Open in browser" button should open the full URI. Try this change.

Wow, that was fast! I built the apk for testing using the latest sources and it works now, thanks a lot.

Right now that is controlled by setting android:autoLink on the text view.
http://developer.android.com/reference/android/widget/TextView.html#attr_android:autoLink

Maybe it can be changed to not auto-link but make the whole text view clickable to open the URL. Be my guest or else I might be able look next week.

Platform: Android 4.0+
Zxing Version: 3.0.1
Barcode Format: PDF417

Since CP437 encoding isn't present on Android I've tried setting different encodings to render a PDF417 barcode but it is prepending extra characters that vary based on the encoding.

US-ASCII
Prepends with 'A'

ISO-8859-1
Prepends with 'AB'

UTF-8
Prepends with 'A\s'

UTF16 prepends stranger characters and actually loses a character from the original source.

Using the following to set the Character set
hints.put(EncodeHintType.CHARACTER_SET, "US-ASCII");

Is there anyway to prevent the rendered barcode from prefixing these characters?

I believe you're seeing the ECI segment. This is how the character set is encoded in the barcode. It's required to interpret it correctly if you're not using the default encoding, so no I don't think it's optional.
Should this actually show up in the scanned data though? I would think the ECI would be just metadata that tells the barcode scanner how to decode the payload which would not include the ECI segment.
No but how are you scanning it? with the library? I thought it handled or at least skipped ECI, but off the top of my head I am not sure.
Scanning with the Barcode Scanner app on Android and at the retailer (Walgreens in this case). We also use the library to scan within our app and all give the same results.
No, the ECI segments are interpreted as text. zxing doesn't skip or handle it correctly in the decoder part.

Making sure I'm reading this right. You're saying it's not a bug in encoding the barcode but rather in scanning and decoding a PDF417 barcode that uses an encoding other than the default?

If that's the case then it should work correctly at the retailer which uses a commericial barcode scanner. This doesn't seem to be the case though.

I need to have a look to verify, but that could well be the case. ECI is an optional part of PDF417 it seems, but seems essential if you use non-standard encoding. It may be that the device also does not parse ECI for what it is.

Is this a patch vs head? that doesn't look like the current last lines of this method. I don't know if my last change is relevant to this change though. You mean you have to handle a shift to byte compaction while in byte compaction?

OK or put another way, it looks like if `MODE_SHIFT_TO_BYTE_COMPACTION_MODE` is encountered in the main loop, it should not go into the `byteCompaction` method at all since it actually does nothing with it and is not triggering a real latch to byte mode. Instead it should just decode the next codeword as a single character.

So at about `DecodedBitStreamParser:114`:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

It seems to give the desired behavior but does it make sense?

In my opinion it makes sense and I would go with your version.
The codeword MODE_SHIFT_TO_BYTE_COMPACTION_MODE (913) is defined in the specs as a temporary switch from text compaction to byte compaction for the next codeword. After that it reverts directly to the previously text compaction sub-mode.

I will apply this change.

There was no previous compaction mode in this case; it was the first code word. I think the default is text compaction and that's OK. The encoder here latches to byte compaction three times to encode the first three chars of `LYL01026278571111222233333` and this sounds weird.

Stepping through the encoder, the logic seems to be:
- No consecutive digits to start, so numeric compaction is out
- 3 consecutive text characters to start, followed by at least 13 digits, all of which are text-encodable, but, text compaction is skipped because it sees a lot of numeric characters coming up within 5 chars, presumably because it wants to make sure to latch to numeric soon to take advantage of numeric compaction then
- Byte compaction sees at least 5 text-encodable characters to start, and so concludes that it should not begin byte compaction here
- It actually rejects all compactions and so defaults to shift to byte mode for 1 character

I think byte compaction is assuming text compaction should take over in cases where text compaction won't.

The difference between the two versions of zxing is the new ECI support for PDF417.
https://github.com/zxing/zxing/issues/27
The PDF417 encoder use the codepage Cp437 by default now if no other codepage is specified.
Before it uses the system default codepage I think.
But the specs of PDF417 says that Cp437 is the default codepage and all other codesets need an ECI segment.
A possible workaround for your devices: you can specify another codeset with EncodeHintType.CHARACTER_SET

@micjahn thanks for this info - which char-set should I take in this case to have the same result as before?

The behavior before was to also use Cp437, which is correct. It is just that it is now configurable too. Not specifying any charset gives the same behavior by default. However as I understand your issue is that this charset isn't supported on Android. If you have a third-party implementation of the Charset that you can bundle, yeah, it should work although I haven't tried it. If it doesn't I imagine it's for a simple and fixable reason.

QR codes, data as they are, are never meant to be executed as if they were programs. Yet most 2D bar codes are capable to encrypt enough information to be a program that could be executed in given platform themselves. All bar code readers should only be given `read` permission. But if a user accidentally given `all permissions` to the bar code reader in his/her device, and later on, scanned a 2D bar code that encrypted binary code targeted at his/her device that exploits system vulnerabilities, that could be worse than anything else.

Is there a way to stop this? Stopping people from encoding programs into bar codes is impractical. But can you also control users and their system so that the reader _never_ gets the permission to execute?

(Questions should go on the mailing list.) QR codes can't encode programs. Well, they can encode whatever they like, but without a reader to actually try to interpret it as instructions, it does nothing. There is nothing like this as part of the QR code spec. So I don't understand this?

I could now reproduce the "wrong code" problem and it was exactly like you said. When I had all formats enabled, PDF-417 was once recognized as "UPC_E". Anyway in our use case we will scan only PDF-417 and we'll restrict the SCAN_FORMATS in the intent to "PDF_417".

In order to compile the project as a library we need to get rid of the switch-case statements. We can only use final fields in case expressions but resource ids are no longer final when the project is compiled as a library.

It is not intended to be used as a library. In the past this has generally just helped people abuse the terms of the license by cloning the UI. However, there is now an `android-core` module which is intended to contain the bits that are truly reusable across apps (i.e. not the UI). If you can identify the particular parts you want to reuse I can look at moving them out to the module, and then you should use `android-core`. This is not going to include things like `CaptureActivity` though.
